story:
The Idea

Ever since I first crossed the Great St. Bernard Pass many years ago, I have had in the back of my mind the idea of a journey on foot, crossing the Swiss Alps from the north, entering Italy and continuing on to Rome.

I've travelled in China, India, South East Asia, North Africa, Europe, and most recently, through Central Asia. A camera has always been part of my luggage, but I've never before travelled more than a few days with photography as the driving force.   

This project is different: the journey to Rome is conceived as the framework for an extended photographic journey, creating an opportunity for a visual exploration.

Beginning in Cologne I will walk south into France where I will join the Via Francigena. After crossing the Jura, the route continues past Lake Geneva, over the Great St-Bernard Pass and on into Italy.

It's nearly 1500 km from Cologne to Rome. At an average of 25 km per day and allowing for contingencies and rest days I will need about 10 weeks to cover the distance.

I'll be travelling light, shooting 35mm black and white film, working simply and offline - no Instagram, no Facebook, no Twitter and nothing to see until I develop the film.

Costs

The costs for such an undertaking fall into several categories:

  • Accommodation
  • Food and drink
  • Photographic material
  • Sundries

I intend to follow the pilgrim path and make use wherever possible of the accommodation available along the way. I'm budgeting for €40/day. To satisfy hunger and thirst I will probably need an added €30.

A  36 frame roll of Ilford HP5, with processing and proofing, costs approx. €8.

I tended in the past to be restrained in my use of film - an average of about 1 roll of film a day has been normal. That could certainly change with this project, and I can anticipate needing 2-3 rolls per day.
 
A rail ticket for the return journey from Rome to Cologne, postage, contingencies and administrative costs round out the financial plan.

Your Support is Invaluable

There are two equally valuable ways in which you can help ensure the success of the project.

A small financial contribution, either in the form of a donation or by selecting a perk, will help cover costs. The encouragement you give in doing so will be invaluable.

The second way in which you can lend your support is by spreading word of the project. Encourage everyone you know - family, friends, enemies - to visit this page and to add their support. 

Here's the link: https://igg.me/at/photographerafoot

That could certainly change with this project, and I can anticipate needing 2-3 rolls per day. A rail ticket for the return journey from Rome to Cologne, postage, contingencies and administrative costs round out the financial plan.Your Support is InvaluableThere are two equally valuable ways in which you can help ensure the success of the project.A small financial contribution, either in the form of a donation or by selecting a perk, will help cover costs. The encouragement you give in doing so will be invaluable.The second way in which you can lend your support is by spreading word of the project. Encourage everyone you know - family, friends, enemies - to visit this page and to add their support. Here's the link: https://igg.me/at/photographerafoot

story:
Go to Vimeo for better video viewing https://vimeo.com/116579811

To view the photographs click on the Gallery Tab above.

Kennedy Brewer and Levon Brooks.  

After more than 30 years behind bars, these men are finally free and trying to put their lives back together. 

I felt compelled to try and tell Levon and Kennedy’s stories in pictures. Photographs are worth a thousand words, and I believe that by putting a face on these cases, it will bring us closer to the reality of wrongful convictions and, as a consequence, help raise awareness about this problem.

This project will also help inform others about the work of innocence projects, not only in Mississippi, but elsewhere, as they work to exonerate innocent prisoners and change public policy.



Kennedy and his girlfriend Omelia.

OUR GOAL:  WRONGFUL CONVICTION AWARENESS CAMPAIGN

Celebrate the enduring spirit and humanity of those who have been wronged. Their lives didn’t end when they got locked up, even for those who were sentenced to death.

We often read about such cases with fleeting outrage, but they mostly remain someone else's very remote and abstract experience.

This book is a permanent photographic tribute to these men -- and all the other men and women like them -- who have been wrongfully convicted.

The photographs will be published by PowerHouse Books and be accompanied by a text about the cases by Tucker Carrington, Director of the Mississippi Innocence Project.  The book release is scheduled for the Fall of 2015 and will coincide with an exhibition of the photographs  in Oxford, Mississippi organized by the local Yoknapatawpha Arts Council (YAC), an Oxford, MS non-profit arts organization.

The exhibition will also feature a documentary film about the cases directed by Joe York, in which Levon and Kennedy tell their own stories. You can find a link to Joe York’s film here: www.mississippiinnocencefilm.org.



Portrait of a Mother; Ms. Annie Brewer, Kennedy's mother.

DETAILS ABOUT OUR CAMPAIGN 

This first exhibition represents the launch of our awareness campaign and will travel  in different US cities. 

The publication is an important part of our multimedia endeavor; it will be on sale at our events, but also in bookstores across the country and will help spread the word about the injustice of wrongful convictions and the work of innocence projects.  

I am grateful to have the support of the best team of professionals in the photographic world;  PowerHouse Books  will publish, publicize and distribute the book and Meridian Printing, a specialist in art and photography books, will print it.  Laumont Photographics will produce, mount, and frame the prints for the upcoming exhibitions. 

http://www.powerhousebooks.com

http://www.meridianprinting.com

http://www.laumont.com



Jeremy, Levon's grandson, and the horse.

FUNDING DETAILS

We are ready to go except for these two final steps: we need to raise $24,000 to subsidize the book production and  $21,000 to frame and ship the exhibition of 65 photographs from New York to Oxford, Mississippi - where the first exhibition will take place.

We hope to exceed our goal and all additional proceeds will be donated to the Mississippi Innocence Project (MIP) to support its efforts to exonerate innocent prisoners and to advance public policy initiatives, including legislation.




Levon and his girlfriend, Dinah.

WHAT YOU GET

The first 200 donors to give $350 or more will receive one print from a special Limited Edition of 200 Fine Art Archival Pigment Prints of: "Portrait of a Mother: Ms. Annie Brewer." All prints will be shipped within 90 days from the end date of our Indiegogo campaign.  Donations are tax deductible.

 
WHO I AM

I am a documentary photographer based in New York City.  Although fascinated by many subjects, I am particularly interested in documenting those among us who are often invisible and ignored by society.  It used to be that besides wealth and status, men and women earned respect because of character.  Spending time with Levon and Kennedy and their families over the past two years was a humbling and unforgettable experience.  Today, I am very happy that I can call them my friends and that they will get some recognition through this project; this body of work is my tribute to them.


Thank you so much for supporting our Wrongful Conviction Awareness Campaign! Please share this story, every effort counts.




The Brewer cousins from left to right, Markeeta, Q, R’nez, Azarion, McKenzie, Bryson and Karli, aka Lulu, Roynika’s baby daughter.

story:
Most of my photography is of perfect structures or about perfect design. My hobby consists of beautiful spaces carefully designed and meticulously prepared for the camera. I am, however, also drawn to photograph an entirely different kind of architecture. These buildings are not new, well maintained, or filled with life. They're empty, abandoned, and worn out. Life has passed them by, and for obvious reasons, they are no longer useful or needed. To me they are mysterious and melancholy, hauntingly beautiful in some strange way, and more fascinating than new structures.

In preparing this collection, I found myself thinking about what draws me to these decaying structures. Why the attraction to these ruins? Have I been trying to tell myself something? Growing up in Izmir, I've always appreciated wide-open spaces and a sense of isolation, but I don't think my interest comes from that. I love history and am attracted to significant sites, but this work is not an expression of that particularly. I've been influenced by artists who create works of emptiness and melancholy, but I am not attempting to emulate those images, either.

Maybe these buildings fascinate me because they represent all of us; maybe they are symbols of our own impermanent status here on earth - metaphors for our transient lives and inability to stop the passing of time. The Bible says that in this world we have no enduring city, but we look forward to a city whose architect and builder is God. Jesus told us not to lay up treasures on earth, where moth and rust corrupt and thieves break in and steal, but to lay up treasures in heaven. Are these buildings reminders or allegories of something we are reluctant to acknowledge? A couple of weeks before my Grandpa died last year, my father and I were helping him out of his bed to go to the bathroom. As he struggled down the hall, he said quietly, "take a good look, boys, this is going to be you sooner than you think." He is right. Our lives go by so quickly and we leave behind the relics of our time here and of what we thought was important. Deep down I know this earth is not my home, that "I'm just passing through," as the old gospel song says.

When I'm around these buildings, I can't help thinking about the life that went on within their walls and wondering what happened to the folks who prayed there. Will someone stand in my church someday and wonder the same things? That makes me a bit uneasy, but it also helps me understand why I find old, worn-out paint, broken walls, and sagging floors in some ways more beautiful than brand new houses, where everything is perfect. I know that someday soon that broken down house is going to resemble me, or my loved ones. Deep down inside I wonder if I'll still be appreciated and valued when I'm no longer productive, have outlived my usefulness, and cost a lot just to maintain, like these buildings. They are relics of another time, of other lives, but they are of my time, too. They are statues, memorializing the transitory nature of life. Ironically, we are frequently moving too fast, erecting the next building and developing the next big thing, to notice these icons or consider what they can teach us about our values. These buildings help me realize the importance of contentment, of being satisfied with what I have.

The photographs in this exhibition were done over a period of twelve years. For the most part, I came across them on the road to or from unrelated trips, and I shot them simply because I found them interesting. As a photographer, traveling is almost always an adventure. I never know when something will capture my attention. Coming across an abandoned building always makes me stop, back up, and go out of my way to explore it. These places energize me and are a joy to photograph. They are an important part of my personal work, and building this body of images has been a labour of love.

story:
Project Summary

I’m heading to Italy this fall to begin work on a We Are 25, a hybrid photography and research project that I truly believe in.  You can read all about it below, and also you can learn about what a huge difference you can make in the success of my project.  

The Mystery, The Story

Sometime in the not-so-distant past, a group of 25 men in poverty-stricken Southern Italy shared an experience so intense that their surnames became Venticinque, literally the Italian word for 25.   What happened, exactly, is where the mystery comes in:

  • Was it a shipwrecked boat of laborers with only 25 heartbroken survivors?
  • A 25-man brigade valorously fighting for (or maybe against) a united Italy? 
  • Some other story of courage and/or tragedy? 

Since then, the original group of 25 has expanded to approximately 1,700, most still in Italy but also spread in pockets worldwide. (Including just over 200 in the US).  We have carried this name-- and its mysteries-- for all this time, yet nobody has conducted a proper exploration or explanation of its origins. I am determined to uncover the answer to the question of how a group of people got a number for their name.

This project is leading me through an in-depth exploration of the name Venticinque: its origin and subsequent storyline, the people who have carried the name through time and space, and what it all tells us about the world we live in.  I am calling this project We Are 25 because it is about the story that we, the descendants of the original 25, can tell together through the process of reconnecting.  

The Project

I recently received the incredible invitation to be Artist in Residence for an Italian language & culture institute in Pennabilli, a tiny town in Northern Italy where I am thrilled to be heading in early September.  While there, I will be working on improving my Italian language skills (I have been studying for years, though in a rather casual capacity) and refining my portraiture style, as well as producing visual media for the institute's marketing needs. I will be working hard while I'm there, and loving the work I'll be doing. 

After my residency concludes in mid-September, I will begin the first major phase of my project We Are 25, traveling down through the South of Italy, specifically the areas around Naples and Calabria and then down to the small village in Sicily that is likely the epicenter of the Venticinque origin story. This southern region is the very land from which many Venticinques fled to escape the extreme poverty, disease, and fascism that was rampant at the time.  While it is estimated that over 4 million Italians (mostly from the South) fled between 1880-1926, one of the unique opportunities that studying the distinctively-named Venticinque family presents is the ability to track them over time and space, and by extension to discover the ties that connect them. 

For the past several years, I have been researching the history and steadily building connections with Venticinques throughout Italy and across the U.S.  I’ve long been curious about what the individuals in the group know about its history and lineage; also, I've grown increasingly interested in the people themselves.  We all share a common name, yet the vast diversity of our life circumstances tells a timely story about immigration and the spectrum between cultural preservation and assimilation.  Now is the moment when I am ready to step into the next phase of my inquiry, when I can finally begin contacting members of the extended Venticinque family to make plans to meet them in person and to create a series of portraits.

Artistically speaking, for this project I will be using classical black & white portraiture techniques, stripping things down to the simplest form to create timeless images.  My goal is to create authentic images that reflect the beauty of each subject, and also blur the lines between the things that so often divide: generations, continents, ethnicities, languages, races.  Each individual portrait tells a story, inviting the viewer to imagine the history behind the subject's face; as a collection of images, they can show the very human way in which we can connect, regardless of the things that may seem to divide us.  

In addition to meeting and photographing these distant cousins (who may or may not be related by blood), I will be conducting interviews and collecting stories.  I am excited to speak with people  about what they know of the meaning and history behind the Venticinque mystery and, even more importantly, about their own lives.  Eventually I will compile these images and narrative accounts into multimedia presentations and public exhibition.

Why this project matters

    •    WeAre25 is, at its root, a story about immigration and its impact through the generations.  Through research, recorded histories and personal stories, there is much to learn from a group of people who fled their homeland, as well as from those who remained.  Considering that there is a worldwide struggle to manage increasing immigration, and Sicily itself is currently experiencing an immigration crisis on a catastrophic scale, this is a perfect opportunity to explore the layers underlying current policies and attitudes.  In addition, Italy is currently experiencing a new wave of white supremacy ("Europe First"); this project is aimed at 

    •    It's a story of culture heritage and how it has been preserved or forgotten.  These days, many of the world's rich and diverse cultures run the risk of being engulfed and erased by a  rootless construct of "whiteness".  It is now more important than ever to resist this outcome by remembering and celebrating our diverse cultural roots, and this project is poised to illustrate that in a compelling and engaging way.

    •     It's a story about ethnicity & race: Southern Italians (and Sicilians in particular) are a genetic kaleidoscope when it comes to race, and their ethnicity is one of the most complex and diverse on the planet.  Over the years, their land has been conquered and inhabited by a variety of people: Arabs, Greeks, Normans, Moors and more.  Because of their complex background and ambiguous ethnicity, Southern Italians offer a unique look into the concept  race and how it has been constructed.  
 

Why me, why now?

One could insist that I was destined to do this project: after all, I was born on 5/25 with the surname "25", an insatiable curiosity, and a passion for photographic storytelling.  I have been dreaming of and laying the groundwork for this project for nearly ten years. but it is this exact moment in time that I am poised to take the first big step in the project.  Thanks to the opportunity to go to Italy for an artistic residency this fall, the time to compete the first stage of We Are 25 has finally arrived.  

Telling stories through photographs is my life's work.  As a longtime professional photographer specializing in portraiture, working with a subject to create a portrait is the most effect way for me to get to know someone.  Collaborating with my subjects, I find that a mutual connection is built; there is something about the mix of my personality plus the vulnerability of being photographed that allows people to open up and share. Creating a beautiful portrait of someone that they love is one of the most important gifts that I have to offer people.  

Over the years, some of my most meaningful and successful photographic work has been my portraits and stories from the road.  Whether it was older gentlemen in the streets of Sicily, the endless crowds and booming sound systems of London's famous Notting Hill Carnival, or any one of the countless beautiful faces I have photographed along the way— chances are that if you've followed my career (or my social media), you have seen some images that caused you to stop and think, and perhaps learn something new about the wider world.  Just this past year, I hosted multiple exhibits of photographs I created during previous travels through Italy; I also delivered a public educational talk about traveling through Southern Italy.

Added to my lifetime of passion for and experience with photography, I also have a background in documentary media & cultural anthropology.  I am deeply interested in people's stories, on both an individual and a group level.  Through this project, I will invite people to share their stories: what is like to live in modern-day Italy, what they know of the family history, how they are positioned in terms of immigration.  Back in the U.S., I will conduct similar sessions with Venticinques, but in these cases my questions will aim to explore how culture has been preserved or lost, whether or not they identify as immigrants, and how they identify themselves in terms of ethnicity and nationality.  I will be gathering these stories and using them in conjunction with the portraits to create a larger work of art.

Simply put: I am called to do this work, and I truly believe in this project.   As I have the opportunity to go to Italy this fall, I want to take full advantage of the chance to launch the first full phase successfully.
 

What I Need & What You Get

I need your help raising the necessary funds to cover my expenses for this stage of my project.  I am asking you -- yes, you! -- for a donation of $25.  I chose this amount for a few good reasons: a25 is my favorite #, b)it's likely to be affordable to most of you, and c) this is the amount I give to pretty much any campaign that directly asks me for support or randomly grabs my attention.

Have more to give?  You’re in luck!  I have some fabulous incentives to entice you to offer a more substantial gift. Your contribution will make a huge difference to me, helping me to cover my significant production costs to make this first major part of my project a reality and to pave the way for its future success.  Check out my incentives— I think they’re pretty great!

Your contribution will help me cover important project-related expenses:

  • Transportation costs: While I'm a pro at traveling on a tight budget, I have an array of transportation needs 
  • Accommodation:  Thanks to my excellent Artist in Residence opportunity, my accommodation is free for the first 2.5 weeks I'm in Italy.  Then from 9/21-10/10, I'm on my own.  My plan is to stay at simple pensiones, Air BnBs, agriturismos, and inns along the way; also, I'm trying to stay with friends (and friends' friends....) whenever possible.  Anywhere safe for me & my gear.
  • Meals on the road.  Fortunately, it's Italy, so the food is inexpensive, plentiful, and delicious!
  • A lightweight tripod that I can easily travel with
  • A lav (clip-on) microphone for video interviews
  • A digital audio recorder
  • Travel Insurance: important to cover my photo gear
  • 2 external hard drives to back all my files 
  • Miscellaneous supplies
  • Emergency just-in-case funds
  • Expenses related to public exhibition/presentations upon my return

You can make it happen

You support will directly enable me to complete this work that I am passionate about and completely dedicated to doing.  It's simple:  without the funds I need, I can't do the work.  But with the backing I need... I'll be able to give my plans & my project the support they deserve. 

I deeply believe that the We Are 25 story, with its focus on a defined group of people, is a valuable opportunity to explore larger themes that are important and timely.  Because this particular case group is so small, it presents a unique opportunity to trace and study a group of people making their way through the world over time.  Not only are the descendants of the original Venticinques easy to identify & locate by their rare and distinctive surname, they also share a bond because of the enigmatic nature of the name itself.

The backing of my community is what will enable me to accomplish my mission.  I know there are many of you who believe in me and the work that I do, and plenty of you whose lives have been directly touched by my photography. Your support means so very much to me.  I am happy and grateful to be living the life of a working artist, but in this case I need to turn to my network to ask for help to make this a reality.  

Next Steps

For more than a year, I have been building relationships with members of the Venticinque network across Italy and the US.  It has been a fun process, and I've found responses from other Venticinques to be surprisingly enthusiastic.  I already have tentative meetings and portrait sessions set up for this fall, and I am beyond ready to get started.  Once I raise enough money to sustain me, I will begin to make travel arrangements and concrete appointments with the first tier of people on my list (starting in Naples).  I can't wait to share what I find with all of you! 

The main purpose of this trip is to gather an initial round of images and stories, laying the foundation of this project which will one day be something much bigger. In the months after I return, I will synthesize what I've gathered to create a presentation for public viewing, offering a series of public viewings and talks.  In early 2019, I will use all that I have gathered create a pitch; I'll bring it to several organizations to request further funding for a larger project:  Italian-American foundations, documentary film producers, cultural research programs, and book publishers.  By funding this critical phase of my project, you are enabling me to create a quality body of work that can stand on its own and serve as a foundation to build to a bigger scale. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I hope that by asking for a manageable $25, a great number of you will be able to comfortably contribute to my campaign.  But even if you're not able to contribute financially, there are other great ways to give your support:

  • Connect me with places to stay.  If you have Italian (or expat) friends who love hosting guests, or have a property with some extra space, I would so appreciate trying to make something work.  I'm an excellent guest, and don't mind having to sing for my supper.
  • Share your travel-related resources (hotel points, sky miles, etc.). Everything helps!
  • Introduce me to my new Italian BFF.  Know someone in Italy and think we'd hit it off?  If you think we'll get along, then I'm happy to meet them with a smile! I love making new friends, and would appreciate any and all connections I can make.
  • Spread the word!  If you can think of someone who would be interested in Italy, immigration history, or portrait photography?  Please share my information with them!  
  • Share my campaign on social media.  This will have a huge impact on my campaign. Please hit "share" and tell people why you think they should consider contributing as well. 
     

Stay connected & follow the journey

For periodic news & updates on my project, sign up for my We Are 25 newsletter.  

Visit my website www.WeAre25.com,   It’s a small spot now, but it will be expanding in the weeks and months to come.  Stay tuned! 
 

Before I say arrivaderci...

Thank you very much for taking the time to read through this.  And thank you for your ongoing  support.  I have faith that by reaching out to many of the beautiful and supportive people I know, I will be able to meet my goal.  After all, it'll only take 160 of you giving $25!  Please consider making a contribution in whatever amount you are able.  I can't wait to share what I discover!

 

In gratitude,

Lisa Venticinque
lisaventicinque@mac.com

Project Summary
I’m heading to Italy this fall to begin work on a We Are 25, a hybrid photography and research project that I truly believe in.  You can read all about it below, and also you can learn about what a huge difference you can make in the success of my project.  
The Mystery, The Story
Sometime in the not-so-distant past, a group of 25 men in poverty-stricken Southern Italy shared an experience so intense that their surnames became Venticinque, literally the Italian word for 25.   What happened, exactly, is where the mystery comes in:

Was it a shipwrecked boat of laborers with only 25 heartbroken survivors?
A 25-man brigade valorously fighting for (or maybe against) a united Italy? 
Some other story of courage and/or tragedy? 

Since then, the original group of 25 has expanded to approximately 1,700, most still in Italy but also spread in pockets worldwide. (Including just over 200 in the US).  We have carried this name-- and its mysteries-- for all this time, yet nobody has conducted a proper exploration or explanation of its origins. I am determined to uncover the answer to the question of how a group of people got a number for their name.
This project is leading me through an in-depth exploration of the name Venticinque: its origin and subsequent storyline, the people who have carried the name through time and space, and what it all tells us about the world we live in.  I am calling this project We Are 25 because it is about the story that we, the descendants of the original 25, can tell together through the process of reconnecting.  
The Project
I recently received the incredible invitation to be Artist in Residence for an Italian language & culture institute in Pennabilli, a tiny town in Northern Italy where I am thrilled to be heading in early September.  While there, I will be working on improving my Italian language skills (I have been studying for years, though in a rather casual capacity) and refining my portraiture style, as well as producing visual media for the institute's marketing needs. I will be working hard while I'm there, and loving the work I'll be doing. 
After my residency concludes in mid-September, I will begin the first major phase of my project We Are 25, traveling down through the South of Italy, specifically the areas around Naples and Calabria and then down to the small village in Sicily that is likely the epicenter of the Venticinque origin story. This southern region is the very land from which many Venticinques fled to escape the extreme poverty, disease, and fascism that was rampant at the time.  While it is estimated that over 4 million Italians (mostly from the South) fled between 1880-1926, one of the unique opportunities that studying the distinctively-named Venticinque family presents is the ability to track them over time and space, and by extension to discover the ties that connect them. 
For the past several years, I have been researching the history and steadily building connections with Venticinques throughout Italy and across the U.S.  I’ve long been curious about what the individuals in the group know about its history and lineage; also, I've grown increasingly interested in the people themselves.  We all share a common name, yet the vast diversity of our life circumstances tells a timely story about immigration and the spectrum between cultural preservation and assimilation.  Now is the moment when I am ready to step into the next phase of my inquiry, when I can finally begin contacting members of the extended Venticinque family to make plans to meet them in person and to create a series of portraits.
Artistically speaking, for this project I will be using classical black & white portraiture techniques, stripping things down to the simplest form to create timeless images.  My goal is to create authentic images that reflect the beauty of each subject, and also blur the lines between the things that so often divide: generations, continents, ethnicities, languages, races.  Each individual portrait tells a story, inviting the viewer to imagine the history behind the subject's face; as a collection of images, they can show the very human way in which we can connect, regardless of the things that may seem to divide us.  
In addition to meeting and photographing these distant cousins (who may or may not be related by blood), I will be conducting interviews and collecting stories.  I am excited to speak with people  about what they know of the meaning and history behind the Venticinque mystery and, even more importantly, about their own lives.  Eventually I will compile these images and narrative accounts into multimedia presentations and public exhibition.
Why this project matters
    •    WeAre25 is, at its root, a story about immigration and its impact through the generations.  Through research, recorded histories and personal stories, there is much to learn from a group of people who fled their homeland, as well as from those who remained.  Considering that there is a worldwide struggle to manage increasing immigration, and Sicily itself is currently experiencing an immigration crisis on a catastrophic scale, this is a perfect opportunity to explore the layers underlying current policies and attitudes.  In addition, Italy is currently experiencing a new wave of white supremacy ("Europe First"); this project is aimed at 
    •    It's a story of culture heritage and how it has been preserved or forgotten.  These days, many of the world's rich and diverse cultures run the risk of being engulfed and erased by a  rootless construct of "whiteness".  It is now more important than ever to resist this outcome by remembering and celebrating our diverse cultural roots, and this project is poised to illustrate that in a compelling and engaging way.
    •     It's a story about ethnicity & race: Southern Italians (and Sicilians in particular) are a genetic kaleidoscope when it comes to race, and their ethnicity is one of the most complex and diverse on the planet.  Over the years, their land has been conquered and inhabited by a variety of people: Arabs, Greeks, Normans, Moors and more.  Because of their complex background and ambiguous ethnicity, Southern Italians offer a unique look into the concept  race and how it has been constructed.   
Why me, why now?
One could insist that I was destined to do this project: after all, I was born on 5/25 with the surname "25", an insatiable curiosity, and a passion for photographic storytelling.  I have been dreaming of and laying the groundwork for this project for nearly ten years. but it is this exact moment in time that I am poised to take the first big step in the project.  Thanks to the opportunity to go to Italy for an artistic residency this fall, the time to compete the first stage of We Are 25 has finally arrived.  
Telling stories through photographs is my life's work.  As a longtime professional photographer specializing in portraiture, working with a subject to create a portrait is the most effect way for me to get to know someone.  Collaborating with my subjects, I find that a mutual connection is built; there is something about the mix of my personality plus the vulnerability of being photographed that allows people to open up and share. Creating a beautiful portrait of someone that they love is one of the most important gifts that I have to offer people.  
Over the years, some of my most meaningful and successful photographic work has been my portraits and stories from the road.  Whether it was older gentlemen in the streets of Sicily, the endless crowds and booming sound systems of London's famous Notting Hill Carnival, or any one of the countless beautiful faces I have photographed along the way— chances are that if you've followed my career (or my social media), you have seen some images that caused you to stop and think, and perhaps learn something new about the wider world.  Just this past year, I hosted multiple exhibits of photographs I created during previous travels through Italy; I also delivered a public educational talk about traveling through Southern Italy.
Added to my lifetime of passion for and experience with photography, I also have a background in documentary media & cultural anthropology.  I am deeply interested in people's stories, on both an individual and a group level.  Through this project, I will invite people to share their stories: what is like to live in modern-day Italy, what they know of the family history, how they are positioned in terms of immigration.  Back in the U.S., I will conduct similar sessions with Venticinques, but in these cases my questions will aim to explore how culture has been preserved or lost, whether or not they identify as immigrants, and how they identify themselves in terms of ethnicity and nationality.  I will be gathering these stories and using them in conjunction with the portraits to create a larger work of art.
Simply put: I am called to do this work, and I truly believe in this project.   As I have the opportunity to go to Italy this fall, I want to take full advantage of the chance to launch the first full phase successfully. 
What I Need & What You Get
I need your help raising the necessary funds to cover my expenses for this stage of my project.  I am asking you -- yes, you! -- for a donation of $25.  I chose this amount for a few good reasons: a25 is my favorite #, b)it's likely to be affordable to most of you, and c) this is the amount I give to pretty much any campaign that directly asks me for support or randomly grabs my attention.
Have more to give?  You’re in luck!  I have some fabulous incentives to entice you to offer a more substantial gift. Your contribution will make a huge difference to me, helping me to cover my significant production costs to make this first major part of my project a reality and to pave the way for its future success.  Check out my incentives— I think they’re pretty great!
Your contribution will help me cover important project-related expenses:

Transportation costs: While I'm a pro at traveling on a tight budget, I have an array of transportation needs 
Accommodation:  Thanks to my excellent Artist in Residence opportunity, my accommodation is free for the first 2.5 weeks I'm in Italy.  Then from 9/21-10/10, I'm on my own.  My plan is to stay at simple pensiones, Air BnBs, agriturismos, and inns along the way; also, I'm trying to stay with friends (and friends' friends....) whenever possible.  Anywhere safe for me & my gear.
Meals on the road.  Fortunately, it's Italy, so the food is inexpensive, plentiful, and delicious!
A lightweight tripod that I can easily travel with
A lav (clip-on) microphone for video interviews
A digital audio recorder
Travel Insurance: important to cover my photo gear
2 external hard drives to back all my files 
Miscellaneous supplies
Emergency just-in-case funds
Expenses related to public exhibition/presentations upon my return

You can make it happen
You support will directly enable me to complete this work that I am passionate about and completely dedicated to doing.  It's simple:  without the funds I need, I can't do the work.  But with the backing I need... I'll be able to give my plans & my project the support they deserve. 
I deeply believe that the We Are 25 story, with its focus on a defined group of people, is a valuable opportunity to explore larger themes that are important and timely.  Because this particular case group is so small, it presents a unique opportunity to trace and study a group of people making their way through the world over time.  Not only are the descendants of the original Venticinques easy to identify & locate by their rare and distinctive surname, they also share a bond because of the enigmatic nature of the name itself.
The backing of my community is what will enable me to accomplish my mission.  I know there are many of you who believe in me and the work that I do, and plenty of you whose lives have been directly touched by my photography. Your support means so very much to me.  I am happy and grateful to be living the life of a working artist, but in this case I need to turn to my network to ask for help to make this a reality.  Next Steps
For more than a year, I have been building relationships with members of the Venticinque network across Italy and the US.  It has been a fun process, and I've found responses from other Venticinques to be surprisingly enthusiastic.  I already have tentative meetings and portrait sessions set up for this fall, and I am beyond ready to get started.  Once I raise enough money to sustain me, I will begin to make travel arrangements and concrete appointments with the first tier of people on my list (starting in Naples).  I can't wait to share what I find with all of you! 
The main purpose of this trip is to gather an initial round of images and stories, laying the foundation of this project which will one day be something much bigger. In the months after I return, I will synthesize what I've gathered to create a presentation for public viewing, offering a series of public viewings and talks.  In early 2019, I will use all that I have gathered create a pitch; I'll bring it to several organizations to request further funding for a larger project:  Italian-American foundations, documentary film producers, cultural research programs, and book publishers.  By funding this critical phase of my project, you are enabling me to create a quality body of work that can stand on its own and serve as a foundation to build to a bigger scale. 
 
Other Ways You Can Help
I hope that by asking for a manageable $25, a great number of you will be able to comfortably contribute to my campaign.  But even if you're not able to contribute financially, there are other great ways to give your support:


Connect me with places to stay.  If you have Italian (or expat) friends who love hosting guests, or have a property with some extra space, I would so appreciate trying to make something work.  I'm an excellent guest, and don't mind having to sing for my supper.

Share your travel-related resources (hotel points, sky miles, etc.). Everything helps!

Introduce me to my new Italian BFF.  Know someone in Italy and think we'd hit it off?  If you think we'll get along, then I'm happy to meet them with a smile! I love making new friends, and would appreciate any and all connections I can make.

Spread the word!  If you can think of someone who would be interested in Italy, immigration history, or portrait photography?  Please share my information with them!  

Share my campaign on social media.  This will have a huge impact on my campaign. Please hit "share" and tell people why you think they should consider contributing as well.  

Stay connected & follow the journey
For periodic news & updates on my project, sign up for my We Are 25 newsletter.  
Visit my website www.WeAre25.com,   It’s a small spot now, but it will be expanding in the weeks and months to come.  Stay tuned!  
Before I say arrivaderci...
Thank you very much for taking the time to read through this.  And thank you for your ongoing  support.  I have faith that by reaching out to many of the beautiful and supportive people I know, I will be able to meet my goal.  After all, it'll only take 160 of you giving $25!  Please consider making a contribution in whatever amount you are able.  I can't wait to share what I discover!
 
In gratitude,
Lisa Venticinquelisaventicinque@mac.com

story:
What is the Art of Skid Row? 

The Art of Skid Row is a tool to reference the need for a new system of housing. Through this book, the human element of Homelessness + Urban Poverty become a visceral experience. The Art of Skid Row is an awareness campaign designed to shift the public perception of homelessness. Homelessness is a human rights issue. The fundamental truth of homelessness is humans not having homes. This book serves as a reminder to the human element of the issue. With the vision of our partner photographers; we take you on a journey to understand the underlying roots, causes and experiences of homelessness.


Featured Artists + Photographers 

Skid Robot: @SkidRobot 
Niaz Uddin: @NeoHumanity

Terry Mclaughlin: @asteryx 

Dylan Schwartz w/ Misha Louy: @dylan.schwartz 

Alania Pierce: @alainapierce

Nadia Tyson: @nadiatyson

Jasper de Jesus: @jasperdejesus

Matt Saatchi: @saatchiphoto

Donna Stellini: @donnakstellini

Ed Freeman: Ed Freeman Photography


We believe it is necessary to take a holistic approach in understanding the needs of all humans on the planet. To ensure a prosperous future for the human condition and experience we need to invest in housing that is affordable for everyone. With the purchase of this book you invest in a long term solution to homelessness and urban poverty. 

The Art of Skid Row: LA was completed in May 2016. The first delivery of books will be in June 2016. This IndieGoGo campaign is raising funds to launch The Art of Skid Row far and wide! Sustaynabl is self-publishing this book to retain control over the use of proceeds. This IndieGoGo will also fund the production of The Art of Skid Row: San Francisco, which will begin recruiting photographers in July 2016! 


Who we are: 

Sustaynabl, Inc is a Benefit Corporation that was founded in 2015. As a Benefit Corporation, we place value on our mission over our profits. Sustaynabl began as a think tank surrounding global issues related to housing, homelessness, and poverty. Working in the City of Los Angeles; which is facing one the largest affordable housing shortages and homelessness issues in the country, we crafted a vision for the future of housing, responsible and sustainable gentrification, economic redevelopment of under-served and underutilized communities, inclusive health care models, and a long-term solution to homelessness. With partners from around the globe, including China’s Broad Group, Poverty Matters, and local Los Angeles partners, we have created a model that addresses the needs of urban housing through scalable investment friendly development. 

We believe it is important to shift the public perception of homelessness to adequately address it.  100% of the profit from the Art of Skid Row is invested in the development + implementation of Sustaynabl Affordable Housing. 10% of the profit is donated to Poverty Matters; which focuses on housing at risk homeless individuals before they lose their affordable housing. 


The Funds

We need your help to expand our awareness campaign. It is our belief that public perception plays a crucial role in addressing homelessness. Homelessness is a human rights issue. With this book, we are able to shift public perception and create a revenue stream to address the issue of homelessness and affordable housing! 

Below is an estimated budget of how the funds will be used. 

$35,000: The Art of Skid Row: LA - Future Printing
$15,000: The Art of Skid Row: SF - Photographers + Book Production 
(July 2016 - December 2016)
$15,000: The Art of Skid Row: Traveling Art Installation, Los Angeles
(July 2016 - October 2016)
$15,000: Social Media Marketing 
$10,000: Marketing Material + Promotional Material for Local Los Angeles Retailers
$5,000: Photographers: Payment to photographers for their contributions to the Art of Skid Row Project. 
$5,000: Administrative/Miscellaneous/Unforeseen Expenses 



The Impact

The Problem: Lack of Affordable Housing caused Homelessness 

The lack of affordable housing is the number one cause of homelessness in the United States. The longer we wait to take action to address homelessness, people suffer. Everyday we hold up the false narrative that homelessness is something that is not easily addressed; people suffer. Everyday we extend that narrative to come up with another reason to not move forward with a long term solution, people suffer.

Housing is the number one expense for low-income, working class, and even middle class families. No other sector of the US economy demands more from a single individual or family than the real estate sector. Affordable housing is an economic issue. The real estate market has not always been as it is today. However, due to the financial crash of 2008 millions of families lost their homes. This created demand in the rental market in towns and cities across the country. Paired with the Millennial generation, now the largest generation in the United States, coming onto the rental market - demand on the housing supply in urban centers has skyrocketed. This demand has far outpaced development in our urban centers. What we are seeing across the country in cities like New York, San Francisco, and most prominently, Los Angeles, will soon affect every major urban center on the planet.

This issue extends far beyond homelessness. This issue is an immediate threat to the prosperity of our future cities. Without a strategic plan to address the housing crisis facing our urban centers in the United States; our cities will be no place to live. This can be seen and experienced today in cities such as Los Angeles; where tents line the streets of our downtown cores, local restaurants and retailers implement customer only bathroom policies - limiting and discriminating bathroom use for homeless individuals, and an overall sense of imbalance as you walk the streets of a developing yet morally decaying city.

The United Nations World Urbanization Prospects findings suggest that in the coming decades there will be a continued migration of people into new and existing Urban Centers. By 2050, it is projected that 66% of our global population will live in urban centers; this equates to 6.4 billion people. Today, our urban centers hold about 3.5 billion people. In order to address the demand over the coming decades we need a strategic plan to invest in affordable housing for all.

We are the wealthiest nation on the planet. We have an abundance of resources available to our nation; and yet, we have millions of people that sleep on the streets by no choice of their own. This is entirely unacceptable. Furthermore, in this time of unprecedented wealth in this country and our planet; homelessness and poverty are a disgrace to humanity. We have a moral imperative to come together as one race, the human race, and solve this issue. 

Our Solution: Sustaynabl Housing

We believe the nature of human experience is shifting to a model where passion and purpose are the metrics by which human life is measured. Experience and human connection will hold greater value than our current monetary metric of social capital. Providing architectural, inspiring, and affordable housing - we open up humanity to a new era of human capital. Artists can be artists. Young persons can feel safe in taking time to find their passion and purpose. Through decreased housing expenses, increased discretionary income, and more time spent in healthy and stable environments, individuals and families will have more opportunity to fully experience their humanity.

It is relevant to understand the underlying issues related to the development process in our urban centers, the current methodologies at work in urban centers across the United States, and across other urban centers that are experiencing and addressing this growth. We believe it is important to understand the roadblocks to development in our cities to adequately address the housing shortages currently being experienced. These roadblocks include access to land + capital, financial markets dictating unprecedented and unnecessary returns on investment, and city regulatory hurdles that prevent scalable and sustainable development from moving forward.

Looking to other cities that have began addressing the issues at hand; we found it imperative to look to the global market. For example, China holds three of the largest urban centers on our planet. China is a model to expand upon for sustainable growth of our future cities. Access to capital, return on investment, and development + construction time are three factors limiting growth in US cities. Sustaynabl’s partnership with Broad Group addresses these issues.

Sustaynabl’s model is to develop Mixed-Income + Mixed-Use Urban Developments in the United States. Through an innovative partnership with the Broad Group, we are able to decrease the cost of development to 40% of similar traditional developments in the United States today. Broad Group has developed specialized prefabricated building technology that allows for drastic cost reduction, waste reduction, and increased building quality and safety. This key feature allows our financial model to provide an excellent return on investment while providing unprecedented impact in a new era of private-public housing solutions.

Following guidelines set by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, Sustaynabl rental rates do not exceed 30% of unit income. All of Sustaynabl’s rental units are affordable. Additionally, our long term solution to homelessness provides at least 10% of our units to at-risk homeless + currently homeless individuals, with a priority on homeless youth - specifically LGBTQ youth in Los Angeles, mothers, families, and veterans. With every Sustaynabl development, we add more transitional homeless housing units to the market. Additionally, we diversify the location of the homeless population across the city. This allows individuals the opportunity to more easily integrate into their new community by removing them from the influences of their past surroundings. This is a continual and exponential strategy to decrease the number of homeless individuals on the streets.

We decrease poverty by building community.

We have developed an impact model that measures the statistical advantages Sustaynabl developments have on communities in which they are developed. Through decreases in housing-related spending, we see an increased stabilization of currently unstable economic communities. Additionally, there is an increase in non-housing spending. This leads to grassroots economic revitalization. This provides boosts to non-housing related sectors of these economies. This, in turn, jump-starts the virtuous cycle of economic prosperity through affordable housing development. 


Risks & Challenges

The book is complete and the first copies will be delivered in June 2016.

Risk: If we do not address the issue of homelessness as a human rights issue; millions of humans in the United States will continue to go without homes. 

Challenges: Our job now is to get this book and project in the hands of millions of Angelenos, Americans, and the Global population to create the movement and energy to address the issue of homelessness once and for all. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Change the dialogue surrounding homelessness. Join our social media campaigns on Facebook or Instagram. Share our posts to shift the perception of people in your social networks. One person, one voice, one share can make an impact!

feature allows our financial model to provide an excellent return on investment while providing unprecedented impact in
a new era of private-public housing solutions.

Following guidelines set by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, Sustaynabl rental rates do not
exceed 30% of unit income. All of Sustaynabl’s rental units are affordable. Additionally, our long term solution to
homelessness provides at least 10% of our units to at-risk homeless + currently homeless individuals, with a priority on homeless youth - specifically LGBTQ youth in Los Angeles, mothers, families, and veterans. With every Sustaynabl
development, we add more transitional homeless housing units to the market. Additionally, we diversify the location of
the homeless population across the city. This allows individuals the opportunity to more easily integrate into their new
community by removing them from the influences of their past surroundings. This is a continual and exponential strategy
to decrease the number of homeless individuals on the streets.

We decrease poverty by building community.

We have developed an impact model that measures the statistical advantages Sustaynabl developments have on
communities in which they are developed. Through decreases in housing-related spending, we see an increased
stabilization of currently unstable economic communities. Additionally, there is an increase in non-housing spending. This
leads to grassroots economic revitalization. This provides boosts to non-housing related sectors of these economies. This,
in turn, jump-starts the virtuous cycle of economic prosperity through affordable housing development. 








    Risks & Challenges The book is complete and the first copies will be delivered in June 2016.
Risk: If we do not address the issue of homelessness as a human rights issue; millions of humans in the United States will continue to go without homes. 
Challenges: Our job now is to get this book and project in the hands of millions of Angelenos, Americans, and the Global population to create the movement and energy to address the issue of homelessness once and for all. 

    Other Ways You Can Help Change the dialogue surrounding homelessness. Join our social media campaigns on Facebook or Instagram. Share our posts to shift the perception of people in your social networks. One person, one voice, one share can make an impact!

story:
English text below!

Testo italiano sotto!

Magyar szöveg alul!

 

/// ENGLISH \\\

3000 km, 45 days, 2 islands, 1 camera – be my companion and yours can be different products.

Let me take you on a journey, to a land where wonder grows. It is a place where shores of gold greet you. Here’s where the spirits of the land tell you tales from long ago. Let me lead you to secrets hidden beneath green hills… to somewhere like nowhere you’ve ever seen.

In the journey to discover this wonderful land… to avoid missing out I have no choice except to go all in. And the fastest way forward is leaving all of my worries behind. This year come with me on an adventure where you have nothing to lose and the only thing to fear is missing out.

Last year I realized that living isn’t the same as being alive. Now that I am here I have learned that the road to self-discovery… starts with a leap of faith. Come with me on a journey where the only way to find yourself is to get lost.

  • Who I am?

My name is Benjámin Kozár. I am from Hungary. I have started learning photography 10 years ago, but as I started to grow up I lost the opportunity to progress in it. At the University and next to work I didn’t have time for it anymore. Last year as I fought my way out of cancer I rediscovered photography again. In March I won the opportunity to study at the University of Otago. It is in Dunedin, New Zealand. It was my dream to visit New Zealand since I first saw The Lord of the Rings in the cinema in 2001. I have fought 17 years to achieve this dream of mine.

  • Why I need Indiegogo?

As I have written in the introduction last year I had cancer. Because of a life saving surgery and chemoteraphy I was out of work for 10 months. During this period I used up all my savings – medicines, CTs, food, travel to hospital etc.

I started working again in 2017. December and now in July I have arrived to Dunedin. This 7 months of work was just barely enough to get enough money for airplane tickets and a few months of food – apart from the study costs.

According to the laws of New Zealand as an international exchange student I am not allowed to work. I started this Indiegogo campaign to get a little bit more money to achieve my dream of seeing New Zealand. It is my childhood dream and I have fought hard for this opportunity to get here. It is highly possible that I will never have the opportunity to get here again.

  • What I am planning to make?

I am planning to do a 45 days trip around the 2 islands. It is more than 3000 km. During this journey I’m going to take a lot of photos. Through the lens of my camera I’m going to present the landscapes, the flora and fauna, and the culture of this land. I am going to make a 3-part photo album, each of it representing one of the previously mentioned areas.

  • When will you get your reward?

According to my plan I will travel back to Europe in the early days of December 2018. The first shipment of the perks will be mailed at the beginning of January 2019.

/// Perks

The pictures are illustrations!

/// ITALIANO \\\

 

3000 km, 45 giorni , 2 isole , 1 sogno - sii mio compagno in questo viaggio e il tuo potrá realizzarsi nel mio album fotografico che sará suddiviso in tre parti e altri prodotti diversi.

Lasciati portare nei magici posti di questa splendida terra, la Nuova Zelanda.. È un posto dove le rive d'oro dell’oceano ti salutano e dove gli spiriti Maori narrano le antiche leggende. Lascia che ti conduca ai segreti nascosti sotto le verdi colline ... in luoghi mai esplorati prima.

Nel viaggo alla scoperta di questa meravigliosa terra… per non perdere nulla delle ricchezze di questa terra non ho altra scelta che dare il 100% . E il modo piú veloce per coglierle é di lasciarmi alle  spalle tutte le mie proccupazioni. Quest’anno vieni con me in un viaggio ricco di scoperte, mistero e magia! Nulla sará piú come prima!

L’anno scorso mi sono reso conto che vivere non é la stessa cosa di essere vivo. Ora che sono qui, sto per imparare che la strada per la scoperta di sé… inizia con un salto di fede. Vieni con me in un viaggio dove l’unico modo per trovarti é quello di perdersi. 

  • Chi sono Io?

Mio il nome è Kozár Benjámin. Vengo dall'Ungheria. Ho iniziato a studiare fotografia 10 anni fa, ma quando ho iniziato a studiare e a lavoraree ho perso l’opportunitá di progredire. All’universitá e al lavoro non avevo piú tempo per farlo. L’anno scorso, mentre lottavo per uscire dal cancro, ho riscoperto di nuova la fotografia. A marzo di 2018 ho vinto l’opportunita di studiare all’Universitá di Otago, é a Dunedin in Nuova Zelanda. Il mio sogno era visitare la Nuova Zelanda fin da quando ho visto Il Signore degli Anelli al cinema nel 2001. Ho combattuto 17 anni per realizzare questo mio sogno, che potrá diventare realtá grazie al tuo prezioso aiuto.

  • Perché ho bisogno di Indiegogo?

Come ho scritto nell’introduzione l’anno scorso ho avuto il cancro. A causa di un intervento chirurgico salva-vita e chemoterapia ero senza lavoro per 10 mesi. Durante questo periodo ho consumato tutti i miei risparmi: medicine, CT, cibo, viaggi in ospedale, ecc.

Ho iniziato a lavorare di nuovo nel dicembre 2017 e ora a luglio sono arrivato a Dunedin. Questi 7 mesi di lavoro erano appena sufficienti per ottenere abbastanza soldi per i biglietti aerei e qualche mese di cibo.

Secondo le leggi della Nuova Zelanda come una studente di scambio internazionale, non ho il permesso di lavorare. Ho iniziato questa campagna Indiegogo per ottenere un po 'più di denaro per realizzare il mio sogno di vedere la Nuova Zelanda. È il mio sogno d'infanzia e ho combattuto duramente per questa opportunità di arrivare qui. È altamente possibile che non avrò mai l'opportunità di tornare qui.

  • Cosa sto progettando di fare ?

Sto pensando di fare un viaggio di 45 giorni attorno alle 2 isole. È più di 3000 km. Durante questo viaggio farò molte foto. Attraverso la lente della mia macchina fotografica ho intenzione di presentare i paesaggi, la flora e la fauna e la cultura di questa terra. Creerò un album di foto in 3 parti, ognuna delle quali rappresenta una delle aree menzionate in precedenza.

  • Quando avrai la tua ricompensa?

Secondo il mio piano, tornerò in Europa nei primi giorni di dicembre 2018. La prima spedizione dei vantaggi sarà inviata all'inizio di gennaio 2019.

/// Ricompense

Le immagini sono illustrazioni!

/// MAGYAR \\\

 

3000 km, 45 nap, 2 sziget, 1 álom – légy az társam ezen az úton és tiéd lehet a 3 részes fotó album és más egyéb termékek.

Hadd vigyelek el egy utazásra, egy olyan országba, ahol minden sarkon új csoda vár. Mikor partot érsz az óceán partján, aranyszínű partok várnak. Itt, hol a föld szellemei régmúlt időkről mesélnek. Hadd, mutassam meg a zöld dombok alatt rejlő titkokat… elviszlek oda, ahol még talán sose láttál.

E csodálatos táj felfedezése során… hogy ne maradjak ki a kalandokból, nincs más tennivalóm, csak, hogy minden aggodalmamat hátrahagyjam és kipróbáljak új dolgokat. Ebben az évben tarts velem egy utazáson, ahol nincs mit vesztened és az egyetlen dolog, amitől tartanod kell az az, hogy kimaradsz.

A tavalyi év során rájöttem élni nem ugyanaz, mint megélni az életet. Most, hogy itt vagyok, megtanultam, hogy az önmagunk megismeréséhez vezető úthoz nem kell más… csak egy kis ugrás az ismeretlenbe. Jöjj velem az úton, ahol az egyetlen módja, hogy megismerd önmagad az-az, hogy el kell veszned az ismeretlenben.

  • Ki vagyok én?

A nevem Kozár Benjámin, sülysápi lakos. 10 évvel ezelőtt kezdtem el a fényképezéssel autodidakta módon tanulni, de ahogy teltek az évek egyre kevesebb időm volt vele foglalkozni. Az egyetemen és munka mellet pedig egyáltalán nem is maradt rá szabadidőm. A tavalyi év során, miközben a rákkal küzdöttem, volt időm „újra felfedezni” a fényképészetet.

Idén Márciusban megadatott a lehetőség, hogy az otagoi egyetemen tanulhassak. Ez az intézmény Dunedin-ben található, Új-Zélandon. Gyerekkori álmom volt, hogy eljussak erre a földrészre – 2001-ben mikor láttam A Gyűrűk Ura című filmet eldöntöttem, hogy ide el kell jutnom. 17 évembe került, hogy megvalósítsam ezt az álmot.

  • Miért van szükségem az Indiegogo-ra?

Ahogy azt a bemutatkozásban is írtam, tavaly rákkal diagnosztizáltak. A műtét és a kemoterápia miatt 10 hónapig ki voltam esve a munkából. Ez idő alatt feléltem minden megtakarításomat felhasználtam – gyógyszerek, utazási költségek, orvosi vizsgálatok, stb.

2017 decemberében kezdtem el újra dolgozni és most Júliusban megérkeztem Dunedin-be. Ez alatt a 7 hónap alatt csak a repülőjegyre és ételre valót sikerült összegyűjtenem – a tanulmányi költségeken kívül.

A jelenlegi szabályozások nem teszik lehetővé, hogy munkát vállaljak az itt tartózkodásom alatt. Azért csináltam ezt az Indiegogo kampányt, hogy egy kis pénzt még tudjak gyűjteni, hogy megvalósítsam az álmomat – látni Új-Zélandot. Gyermekkorom óta erre vágyom és sokat küzdöttem érte, hogy ez megvalósuljon. Azonban egyedül idáig jutottam és most szükségem van a segítségetekre. Valószínű, hogy többé nem tudok ide visszajutni.

  • Mit tervezek csinálni?

Egy 45 napos túrát tervezek a 2 sziget körül. Ez több mint, 3000 km-es utat jelent. Utazásom alatt rengeteg fényképet fogok csinálni és a kamerámon keresztül szeretném bemutatni a Föld ezen kis szegletének élővilágát, kultúráját és tájait. Utazásom végén egy 3 részes fényképalbumot állítok össze melyekben az előzőekben felsorolt témák közül lesznek fényképek.

  • Mikor kapod meg a „Jutalmad”?

Terveim szerint December elején már Európában leszek. Az első „jutalmak” 2019. Január elején lesznek postázva.

/// JUTALMAK

A képek illusztrációk!
