story:
WHAT IS IT?

The 48 States project is a solo road trip to photograph federally designated wilderness areas and National Wildlife Refuges in the lower 48 states. A book featuring the best photos from the trip, a website with info on places visited and an exhibit will be produced at the end.

To make fundraising and budgeting easier I'll be doing the project in stages. First up is the Southeast from Virginia to Florida and then back up towards Kentucky and West Virginia. 

WHY DO IT?

Wildlands in the United States are under constant attack by corporate and political interests from mountaintop removal mining in the Appalachians to tar sands oil extraction in the Midwest and wetlands loss due to dredging and canals in the gulf states. I believe it's important to show the beauty of these places before they finally get their way and destroy the land and lock the public out of using them for recreation.


WHY NOT 50 STATES?

Simply because of the expense. I would love to add Alaska and Hawaii to the project but that would almost double the cost. If this is successful hopefully I can add them in the future.

SO WHAT DOES THE MONEY GO TO?

Almost a third of it will be gas and vehicle expenses. Around another third will go towards fees and reward fulfillment and the final third will be for food and travel expenses. Other than some random camping gear I have most of what I need as far as equipment goes. The fundraiser won't be the only source of money for the trip but it won't happen without it. Any money left over at the end will either go towards making a better exhibit or adding pages to the book.
I'm using Indiegogo's flexible funding option which means even if I don't raise the full amount I still get whatever is raised just at a higher fee. If I do come in under the goal I'll just reduce the number of states visited initially and try to add them in later. If I only raise 50 dollars well I guess I can go on an overnight trip near my home and still deliver at least a nice photo to you.


WHO IS INVOLVED?

I'm Kent Moore. A Roanoke, Virginia based photographer. The last few years I've mostly been photographing abandoned buildings and places from Ohio to New Orleans to South Carolina. Over the years though I've probably best been known for documenting the local punk rock music scene. Most of my published work has been of those photos. I've self-published two books so far so I know the process of doing that. Here's my main website. 
I hope to enlist a few other team members to do some writing and graphic design for the project.


WHAT DO I GET.

I've set the perks up so you get a physical product at all designated levels. None of those “I'll give you a high five” or just a thanks on a web page most people won't click on. Of course I'll still give you a high 5 and a thanks no matter how much you contribute but an actual print you can hang on the wall is a bit better I think.

GENESIS

I've been sitting on and dreaming about an adventure like this for about 17 years. It started when I read Earth Odyssey by Mark Hertsgaard. In it he went around the world to 19 countries reporting on various environmental crises. I'm not a reporter or a writer so it was hard to come up with a similar plan that would still tell a story. I am a photographer though and eventually started coming up with a plan to tell an environmental story through photos. I've kicked around several ideas that would have taken me to the Amazon jungle, the forests of Vietnam among other exotic locales. Those ideas were discarded for various reasons, complexity, time constraints, costs, etc. I may come back to them in the future if things work out right. More recently I started thinking that maybe I should do something closer to home. Of course once I started brainstorming it it grew to still a fairly complex and expensive undertaking. Since it's all contained to one country though it will be much easier to pull off.

ANY RISKS?

Oh yeah. The biggest will be potential vehicle problems. From flat tires to the engine blowing up to getting broadsided by a moose almost anything is possible when you plan on driving in the 13-15,000 mile range. I plan on putting full insurance coverage and a roadside assistance plan on the vehicle to reduce the hassles of any thing like that that arises.

Another is health issues. Most of the east coast portion should be pretty simple but for parts of the west coast and Rocky Mountains I'll be out in the woods or desert for weeks at a time. Since I’ll be solo in some rugged and remote places I will be a bit more cautious than I might be if I was with friends here in the Blue Ridge. A simple task like crossing a creek can turn dangerous really fast if you get reckless.



I'M BROKE CAN I STILL HELP?

Definitely. Please share this page with your friends and network. I'm also accepting sponsorships. Anything from camping or photo gear to cans of food I'll accept and list you on the sponsors page. Please contact me with any ideas you have for that, no matter how insignificant it might seem it could be a huge help.

story:
EAST COAST: ARCTIC TO TROPIC

My name is David Freese and I am a photographer who lives and works in Philadelphia, PA.  I am seeking your support to complete the financing of my new book – East Coast: Arctic to Tropic.  At the end of this book information and request, please be sure to read the section regarding the limited edition prints available as perks starting at the $250 level.

Climate change commands our attention.  Photographs provide evidence and perspective which are crucial to help us understand the consequences of inaction.  The threat of rising seas to coastal communities around the world is real and potentially disastrous. The East Coast of North America is especially at risk.  When Hurricane Sandy hit New York City and the New Jersey shore in October of 2012, we had a terrible preview of what can and will happen to our low lying shores.

That event was the catalyst for me to undertake and embark upon a 7000 mile photographic odyssey – East Coast: Arctic to Tropic. These images place this extraordinary yet fragile coastline in an environmental context with the rising Atlantic Ocean.  Many of the images are taken from the air. The view from above truly shows our precarious relationship to the sea yet we observe a stunningly beautiful seacoast with many twists and turns. The Atlantic Seaboard is remarkably diverse and often surprising as we travel south from the Arctic circle to just above the Tropic of Cancer – glaciers, fjords, national parks, great cities, roadways and bridges are a feast for the eyes.

 It takes over $45,000 to bring a book of this magnitude to fruition and I am very pleased to say that we have $35,000 in place.  With your kind support and contributions, I hope to bridge and even surpass that gap.  The book will be 10 X 12 inches in size and contain 330 pages with 188 photographs.  The bestselling author Simon Winchester has written a most engaging and informative text that describes all the processes in play and Jenna Butler, a wonderful Canadian author, has written a fine essay that indeed provides the Canadian perspective. 

East Coast will also be a companion to my first book West Coast: Bering to Baja. There, earthquakes and volcanoes are the ongoing threat as the powerful forces of tectonic plates grinding and crashing into one another create the breathtaking scenery. In contrast, the East Coast, which is geologically stable, faces a formidable Atlantic Ocean that is rapidly rising above our shores. We burn fossil fuels, carbon dioxide levels increase, greenhouse gases are trapped, temperatures warm, ice melts, the oceans rise.

It is a straightforward equation and is indicative of the fact that the only climate that really matters is the one in which we find ourselves.

The reality of global warming is evidenced by retreating ice all over the world. I saw it first hand at the Jacobshavn Ice Fjord where water pours out of the rapidly melting Greenland Ice Sheet. A complete melt of the ice cap would add 22 feet to sea levels worldwide. And that excludes the melting Antarctic.

Our predicament is our own doing, an undoing is a monumental challenge when there is political opposition to nature’s reality for purely ideological reasons and when science is purposefully ignored.

Human beings can be clever, resourceful, and ingenious. The challenge is whether or not we can harness and master our skills and use new technologies and policies in a worldwide endeavor to save and protect our future whereabouts.  These images will no doubt become a reference point for succeeding generations. Many of the areas I photographed will be underwater—only the time frame is in question.  This book is meant to heighten awareness by letting people see for themselves – through the arts of photography and writing – our relationship to the vast water which covers 70% of the globe. Thank you so very much for watching and listening.  Your support is greatly appreciated.

PERKS:  At the $250, $500 and $1,000 levels, I will be sending each contributor an actual signed limited edition archival pigment print. I will select one image from the book to be printed only for this fundraising campaign. This one image will be printed at all sizes offered up to the $1,000 level.  In other words, you will have a unique, signed, limited edition print that will not ever again be offered for sale to anyone at any size. The final number of the edition is dependent upon the number of contributions that qualify for that print; the edition numbering will begin in the order of date of contribution independent of size. 

At the $1500, $2,000, $2,500 and $3,500 levels, the donor may select the image desired from the book which, of course, I will send to you first. The print will be part of a signed limited edition of 10 prints. In other words, these prints will also be available to collectors or institutions but only 10 prints will ever be offered at that size. My work is in many museum, university and corporate collections including the Denver Art Museum, Cleveland Museum of Art and the Library of Congress. See the bio on my website for more information about myself and other photographic projects that I have completed. www.davidfreesephoto.net

You can see a preview of more images from East Coast Bering to Baja at LensCulture. https://www.lensculture.com/david-freese-2

Print Information:  The prints are made on Hahnemuhle Photo Rag Bright White paper using Epson K3 Ultrachrome inks. Note: Prints are unframed and not matted.

Shipping Outside the U.S.:  I will ship outside the United States but I will have to quote shipping charges at that time.

story:
The little big idea

Penguins! is a special small coffee table book showcasing iconic new photographs by renowned photographer, Marc Hoberman, of South Africa's adorable (and sadly, highly endangered) Jackass Penguins. Surprisingly, despite the fascinating subject, such a book doesn't exist and with your help we can create something super special that will help educate and inspire future generations to protect these incredible birds. 

50% of the proceeds of book sales will go to SANCCOB to help build a new, much-needed, seabird hospital in Cape Town. They are an incredible and much celebrated organisation that we have worked with for years and as a non-profit, they need all the help that they can get. 

 

Treats!

We're hoping to raise $5000 to help go towards the production of the book. The print quality will be out-of-the-ordinary - with silk cloth hardcover, triple-coated art papers, gold foiled titles etc. An "average" book on the subject will just not do!

Your help will be greatly appreciated (you can receive a free hug if you are in Cape Town) from us, SANCCOB and, of course, the birds. We're offering some exciting exclusive perks including signed books, exclusive screensavers, limited signed and numbered art prints and even a chance to adopt and name a penguin!!

 

The Impact

Your help will result in a very special book that will inspire and educate and in turn help towards the building of a sea bird hospital. I've been producing books for over 20 years (starting at 12 years old!) so you can have the confidence that the project will go ahead and will be something very special - you can see more about my books at www.hobermanbooks.com

Thank you!!

Marc and the Penguins!

That's me and my San Tribe friends while working on my book "Namibia" 2015. For my Penguins! picture I'll be sure to wear a tuxedo :D

story:
The book is available here: https://www.ovidiugordan.com

 

About the book

As a visual artist I can only say I am blessed to be born in Romania.  In my country almost everything is a picture, I do not have to search for images, I just live my life and pictures happen. Actually the more I live my life the better my images get.  People here have a specific quality, a sort of external image of poverty mixed in together with profound internal abundance and creativity. A wonderful balance of roughness and sensibility. It all just comes together  naturally, like an old pair of shoes you’ve worn thousands of times, they look worn out but their your favorite pair, their comfortable, and then there’s all the memories you have together, places you’ve been, people you’ve met. You look at them and they make you smile.

Family pictures work the same way, there is the picture, the actual physical photograph and then there is the memory attached to it, the metaphysical or spiritual side of the image. My approach to photography is similar to the family snapshot but somehow it is the opposite, I already have the memory and I am now searching or rather waiting for the memory to manifest itself. The result is strangely familiar.

The dream

Publishing a book of my photographs has been a creative dream of mine for many years. I believe a photobook is the best and most intimate way you can experience photography. I feel my images are all about intimacy and so the best way to enjoy them will be in a wonderfully printed photobook.

Please consider supporting the production and printing of my photobook, your contributions will help my images get out into the world.

Technical stuff

The pictures in the book were taken with a Nikon FM2n, 35mm film camera and I used both color and black and white film.  

  • All the images are scanned and calibrated, ready for printing.
  • I have the final selection and the sequence of the images made.
  • I wrote a small essay for the book and had my artist friends help me with the book design and the illustrations for the cover.
  • I made a dummy book just to see how the book will physically work and if I need to change anything.

The book will be 23 x 23 cm , hardcover, it will have a total of 108 pages and 52 photographs.

This book will have a Limited Edition run of 300 copies.

All the funds from this campaign will go into the production and printing of the phoobook.

Collaborations

For the actual printing I will work with IDEA  publishing house in Cluj Napoca, one of the best in Romania.

I am also collaborating with photographer and print specialist Márton Zoltán from Cluj-Napoca to inshore the best print quality for my photobook.

Other Ways You Can Help 

If you like my project and feel like pre-ordering a copy of my  photobook or just contributing in any way that would be AMAZING! 

Also If you can't support the book financially, please share my campaign with your friends and ask your friends to share it with their friends.

Thank you so much!

Useful links

My website: www.ovidiugordan.com

My Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/ovidiugordanartist/  

If you need to ask anything or just say hello, please e-mail me at ovigordan@gmail.com

story:
The things you are passionate about are not random,

they are your calling.This quote is one of my favorites, because I'm living it.  

15 Years ago someone close to me asked me a question that would forever change my course in this life.  The question was "If you could do this for a living would you?"  My heart said yes, but the rest of the world started to says no to these types of paths.  If it wasn't for someone taking a moment, realizing I had a gift that should be shared, and pushing me to pursue it, I would be on a very different path. I can feel it in my soul that this path I'm along is where I"m meant to be.

This is why I believe in following your passions in this life, and having a place that will cultivate a creative community.

My name is Carrie Stadelman and I'm a Certified Professional and Master Photographer .

  • This campaign will help make the dream of having a place for not only Freeland Photography Portraiture, but a place for creatives, young artists and women entrepreneurs to get a sense of community and support. To build a foundation in pursuing the paths less taken, and fulfilling the purpose we have in this life.
  • Having a place to bring artists, creatives, and entrepreneurs together to lean on one another and support each other is the main goal.  I love finding new talent and helping them bring it into the world.

I have a list of things I want this place to be and this is only just the beginning. 

 

A PLACE TO START

This campaign will help me finalize the work that needs to be done to get the studio ready for portraiture and community.  Getting new lights for the ceiling that are LED and promote better lighting for photos and video.  New Equipment to help run the studio better, as well as construction items to finish off different spaces.  Furniture will be added so when events take place here, we have a place for discussion and togetherness. Being able to get this done will help me launch the different projects for our community sooner. Also new signage for the front of the building and doors, as well as out front so the public knows where we are!

YOUNG ARTIST RECEPTION.

My first project is to host a quarterly young artist reception to show the community a new and emerging artist or entrepreneur.  This can be someone who does anything that isn't the "normal" path.  I want to help showcase these artists so they can start finding their passions and have them lead into their purpose.  No longer should they hide away their talents and not know what it feels like to be appreciated and accepted.  Knowing they can use these talents in their life and careers will help them carve our their niche in the future.

 

BACKER REWARDS....THE GOODIES!

 

I love a good behind the scenes, so you will be able to get a first look at our studio as it changes and grows through our social media and newsletter.  Having the pride to know you personally made this dream come true is a great reward, but I know you want some good stuff.  Take a look at what our perks are and make your selection now!

 

The Impact

By becoming a backer, you will help not just build my dream, but those who find solace in this community and creative space:

  • I want people to know that it is ok to pursue their passions and gifts in this life.
  • Helping others in the community is something that makes my heart happy. In partnership with the Cascades Humane Society, We have done a Calendar Contest for 9 years which has raised over $30,000 dollars in fundraising dollars for CHS in just one year.  
  • When you donate to our campaign, it's not just our studio that advances, it will be all those who think they can't make their dream a reality that will benefit.

Other Ways You Can Help

I totally get it, it's a hard time in our world. Here are some ways to help our campaign even if you can't be a backer.

  • Get the word out to your community on social media or in person. Share our link to your family and friends and let them know about the awesome perks we have available.
  • When you share, we will do a little dance too!

And that's all there is to it.

Get the word out to your community on social media or in person. Share our link to your family and friends and let them know about the awesome perks we have available.
When you share, we will do a little dance too!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Intro

IT: Dal 2014 al 2017 ho realizzato un reportage in Marocco documentando una particolare forma di autolesionismo molto diffusa tra i giovani marocchini (usata come codice di appartenenza al gruppo) che l'opinione pubblica chiama ‘tcharmil’.

Con il tuo aiuto potrò pubblicare questa storia attraverso una fanzine, cioè una rivista stampata su carta da giornale in dimensione tabloid.

ENG: From 2013 to 2016 I shooted a reportage in Morocco documenting a particular form of self-harming very common among young Moroccans (used as a code of belonging to the group) that the people call "tcharmil". With your help I will be able to publish this story through a fanzine, that is a magazine printed on newspaper in tabloid size.

IT: Se darai il tuo contributo potrai anche avere, oltre alla fanzine appena stampata, delle stampe fine art di alcune immagini o il poster in formato A2 su carta da affissioni…dipende dalla tua generosità.

ENG: If you fund my project you can also have, in addition to the newly printed fanzine, some fine art prints and/or the A2 format poster on billboard ... it depends on your generosity.

L'autolesionismo in Marocco / Self-harming in Morocco

IT: Poche persone al di fuori del Marocco conoscono il fenomeno "tcharmil". Un movimento giovanile nato negli ultimi anni anche in conseguenza alla chiusura delle frontiere con l'Europa. Il modo di vita tcharmil si ispira alle gang di stampo americano: abbigliamento sportivo o firmato, capelli rasati con figure tribali, orologi appariscenti, collane ed anelli luccicanti e, quasi sempre, numerose cicatrici sulle braccia, sul torso e sul collo.

Questo modo di scarificarsi ha origini ancora più antiche in Marocco ma i giovani tcharmil lo hanno adottato come linguaggio contemporaneo, come rappresentazione di appartenenza e mezzo per scatenare l'orrore sociale. Un modo per simboleggiare il loro male di vivere ma anche l'assenza di limiti e paure.

ENG: Few people outside of Morocco know about the "tcharmil" phenomenon. A youth movement born in recent years also as a result of the closure of the borders with Europe. The tcharmil way of life is inspired by American-style gangs: sportswear or italian fashion clothing, hair shaved with tribal signs, flashy watches, shiny necklaces and rings and, almost always, numerous scars on the arms, torso and neck.

This way of scarifying has even more ancient origins in Morocco but the young tcharmil have adopted it as a contemporary language, as a representation of belonging and a means to unleash social horror. A way to symbolize their evil of living but also the absence of limits and fears.

Cosa c’è in palio? / What is up for grabs?

IT: Purtroppo la stampa roto-offset richiede una alta tiratura (solitamente migliaia di copie), cosa che non è necessaria in questo caso ma devo comunque pagare un elevato costo di avviamento macchina. Di conseguenza ho scelto questa piattaforma per finanziare il progetto e in cambio offro:

1- Sconto sul prezzo della fanzine

2- Poster tipo ‘wallpaper’ formato A2 (60x42 cm circa)

3- Un set di tre stampe fine art originali ed autografate in formato 21x29 cm

ENG:  Unfortunately, roto-offset printing requires a large print run (usually thousands of copies), which is not necessary in this case but I still have to pay a high cost for the start up of the printing press. Consequently I chose this platform to finance the project and in return I offer:

1- Discount on the price of the fanzine

2- A2-style blueback wallpaper (about 60x42 cm)

3- A set of three original fine art prints signed in A4 size (about 21x29 cm)

Un altro modo per aiutarmi? Another way to help me?

IT: Condividi questa pagina e chiedi ai tuoi amici se sono interessati...insomma, spargi la voce! Grazie.

ENG: Share this page and ask your friends if they are interested ... spread the word! Thank you.

IT: Condividi questa pagina e chiedi ai tuoi amici se sono interessati...insomma, spargi la voce! Grazie.ENG: Share this page and ask your friends if they are interested ... spread the word! Thank you.

story:
Che Plays Chess, Mantanzas, 1993

 

Six years. Twelve month-long trips.  25,000 images.

The genesis of this project began with my first trip to Cuba in 1990. Having grown up in the Virgin Islands I was searching for a place to photograph that had escaped homogenization and commercialization. Inaccessible, enigmatic Cuba shown like a beacon of unadulterated light, and after one trip I knew I had found what I was looking for.

 In 1989, Cuba began its downward financial spiral as economic ties with the Soviet Union frayed. While politics had never been the impetus of my interests, it was impossible to separate Cuba’s current state of affairs from its daily life unfolding around me. It became very clear very quickly that this complex and intriguing country could not be understood in a single visit. What started as one trip turned into a series of month-long journeys taken over the course of six years. 

Girl with Dog, Caibarien, 1992

Immersing myself in Cuba’s history, literature, and politics, I explored the island, developing relationships, and witnessing extraordinary change that was stimulating and enlightening, as well as disheartening and disturbing. Against often melancholy backdrops, the subtleties and layered complexities of day-to-day Cuba were arresting and compelling. With urgency, I photographed everything; interiors of homes and businesses, city streets, rural landscapes, signs and billboards, and, poignantly the people, creating a considered body of work born from complete engagement and informed perspective.

One hundred of the 25,000 images, with a selection of writings by some of Cuba’s most important writers, comprised Cuba: The Elusive Island, my my 1996 book, now currently out of print, published by Harry N. Abrams. The Museum of Modern Art acquired several images in the book, and the work was exhibited in Havana and New York City. Until recently the images were in storage. Two years ago, I began to create digital files to preserve the original 6 x 9 negatives. Re-editing the images through a prism of time and historical change, I found myself transfixed by the many previously overlooked images that comprise the approximately 500 images in The Cuba Archive.

Gun Pen, Las Tunas, 1993

Now, twenty-six years since my first visit, foreign investment, development, and political changes have progressively altered the landscape I knew so intimately. Politics are forever intrinsically intertwined, and recent profound and historical changes will continue to make their mark on Cuba at an accelerated pace.

Damiani Editore, a noted fine art press in Bologna, Italy, would like to publish The Cuba Archive, a book of 120 of these images in fall 2017. Together, with your support, and with my considerable personal investment, I’d like to actualize this 1,500-copy limited edition of The Cuba Archive.

Photographs from The Cuba Archive will be prominently featured in a 2017/2018 exhibition on Cuba at the Annenberg Space for Photography, Los Angeles, California, part of the Getty Museum’s Pacific Standard Time upcoming program.

Havana Libre Hotel Lobby, 1993

Content:

The Cuba Archive is a considered portrait of this place and its people. The comprehensive archive project documents and preserves an intimate perspective of 1990s Cuba.

The book features 120 photographs with an essay by Silvana Paternostro, noted Colombian-born journalist and senior fellow at the World Policy Institute. The book is designed by award-winning designer Yolanda Cuomo, whose work on numerous books includes retrospectives of such legendary photographers as Richard Avedon, Robert Capa, and Diane Arbus.

The Cuba Archive ships September 2017.

Specs:

  • 176 pages long, featuring 120 photos, essays, and captions
  • Offset printed and bound in Bologna, Italy by Damiani Editore
  • Hardcover, Smyth sewn
  • Printed 4 colors + varnish on the images on coated matte paper 170 gr.;
  • The cover and spine will be debossed with the title. 
  • Book size is 29.3 x 21 cm, landscape format

Shark Speakers, La Playa, 1992

 

My Story:

I first picked up a camera at age eight, while growing up in the Virgin Islands. A New York City photographer for more than 25 years, I have pursued both commercial shooting and personal long-term projects ranging from Cuba to projects on New York’s Lower East Side, the Philippines, my family and our ancestral Rhode Island home, and my own Sag Harbor back yard

In spring 2012 Damiani published Sand Sea Sky: The Beaches of Sagaponack. The 63 images selected from a 10,000-image looks at my decade-long meditation on nature’s transient fragility and radiance. Carl Safina, Blue Ocean Institute president, scientist, and award-winning author contributed an essay.

My work has been published in Aperture, Harpers, Geo, Travel & Leisure, Smithsonian, and Vogue, among many other publications, and exhibited in New York City, Athens, Greece, Washington, DC, Chicago, Illinois, and Havana, Cuba.  My photographs are included in the permanent collections of The Museum of Modern Art, The Brooklyn Museum, The Parrish Art Museum, The Jewish Museum, and The NY Public Library.

Time frame:

 

·       April  1 2017 – May 15 2017 – Indiegogo Campaign

 

.      May 31 2017 - Book design deadline

·       June 2017 – Production and quality check

.       June  2107-Printing-Bologna, Italy

 ·       September 2017 – Shipping

 

Where’s the Money Go? I am asking for support for 75% of the total cost ($48,000.):

 

  • book printing and production (28,000)
  • book design, writing, copy editing, and editing (12,000)
  • shipping cost  (2000)
  • file preparation, conversions, and match prints (6000)

 

A heartfelt THANK YOU in advance for your support and participation in the preservation of this important historic archive.

P.S. Please make sure to select your perk; don't just hit the pink "back it" button unless you only want to donate toward the project. Thank you!
story_txt:
Che Plays Chess, Mantanzas, 1993 Six years. Twelve month-long trips.  25,000 images.The genesis of this project began with my first trip to Cuba in 1990. Having grown up in the Virgin Islands I was searching for a place to photograph that had escaped homogenization and commercialization. Inaccessible, enigmatic Cuba shown like a beacon of unadulterated light, and after one trip I knew I had found what I was looking for. In 1989, Cuba began its downward financial spiral as economic ties with the Soviet Union frayed. While politics had never been the impetus of my interests, it was impossible to separate Cuba’s current state of affairs from its daily life unfolding around me. It became very clear very quickly that this complex and intriguing country could not be understood in a single visit. What started as one trip turned into a series of month-long journeys taken over the course of six years. Girl with Dog, Caibarien, 1992Immersing myself in Cuba’s history, literature, and politics, I explored the island, developing relationships, and witnessing extraordinary change that was stimulating and enlightening, as well as disheartening and disturbing. Against often melancholy backdrops, the subtleties and layered complexities of day-to-day Cuba were arresting and compelling. With urgency, I photographed everything; interiors of homes and businesses, city streets, rural landscapes, signs and billboards, and, poignantly the people, creating a considered body of work born from complete engagement and informed perspective.One hundred of the 25,000 images, with a selection of writings by some of Cuba’s most important writers, comprised Cuba: The Elusive Island, my my 1996 book, now currently out of print, published by Harry N. Abrams. The Museum of Modern Art acquired several images in the book, and the work was exhibited in Havana and New York City. Until recently the images were in storage. Two years ago, I began to create digital files to preserve the original 6 x 9 negatives. Re-editing the images through a prism of time and historical change, I found myself transfixed by the many previously overlooked images that comprise the approximately 500 images in The Cuba Archive.Gun Pen, Las Tunas, 1993Now, twenty-six years since my first visit, foreign investment, development, and political changes have progressively altered the landscape I knew so intimately. Politics are forever intrinsically intertwined, and recent profound and historical changes will continue to make their mark on Cuba at an accelerated pace.Damiani Editore, a noted fine art press in Bologna, Italy, would like to publish The Cuba Archive, a book of 120 of these images in fall 2017. Together, with your support, and with my considerable personal investment, I’d like to actualize this 1,500-copy limited edition of The Cuba Archive.Photographs from The Cuba Archive will be prominently featured in a 2017/2018 exhibition on Cuba at the Annenberg Space for Photography, Los Angeles, California, part of the Getty Museum’s Pacific Standard Time upcoming program.Havana Libre Hotel Lobby, 1993Content: The Cuba Archive is a considered portrait of this place and its people. The comprehensive archive project documents and preserves an intimate perspective of 1990s Cuba.The book features 120 photographs with an essay by Silvana Paternostro, noted Colombian-born journalist and senior fellow at the World Policy Institute. The book is designed by award-winning designer Yolanda Cuomo, whose work on numerous books includes retrospectives of such legendary photographers as Richard Avedon, Robert Capa, and Diane Arbus.The Cuba Archive ships September 2017.Specs: 
176 pages long, featuring 120 photos, essays, and captions
Offset printed and bound in Bologna, Italy by Damiani Editore
Hardcover, Smyth sewn
Printed 4 colors + varnish on the images on coated matte paper 170 gr.;
The cover and spine will be debossed with the title. 
Book size is 29.3 x 21 cm, landscape format
Shark Speakers, La Playa, 1992 My Story: I first picked up a camera at age eight, while growing up in the Virgin Islands. A New York City photographer for more than 25 years, I have pursued both commercial shooting and personal long-term projects ranging from Cuba to projects on New York’s Lower East Side, the Philippines, my family and our ancestral Rhode Island home, and my own Sag Harbor back yardIn spring 2012 Damiani published Sand Sea Sky: The Beaches of Sagaponack. The 63 images selected from a 10,000-image looks at my decade-long meditation on nature’s transient fragility and radiance. Carl Safina, Blue Ocean Institute president, scientist, and award-winning author contributed an essay.My work has been published in Aperture, Harpers, Geo, Travel & Leisure, Smithsonian, and Vogue, among many other publications, and exhibited in New York City, Athens, Greece, Washington, DC, Chicago, Illinois, and Havana, Cuba.  My photographs are included in the permanent collections of The Museum of Modern Art, The Brooklyn Museum, The Parrish Art Museum, The Jewish Museum, and The NY Public Library.Time frame: ·       April  1 2017 – May 15 2017 – Indiegogo Campaign .      May 31 2017 - Book design deadline·       June 2017 – Production and quality check.       June  2107-Printing-Bologna, Italy ·       September 2017 – Shipping Where’s the Money Go? I am asking for support for 75% of the total cost ($48,000.): 
book printing and production (28,000)
book design, writing, copy editing, and editing (12,000)
shipping cost  (2000)
file preparation, conversions, and match prints (6000)
 A heartfelt THANK YOU in advance for your support and participation in the preservation of this important historic archive. P.S. Please make sure to select your perk; don't just hit the pink "back it" button unless you only want to donate toward the project. Thank you!

story:
The First 100 Days of Activism

Since taking office on January 20, Donald Trump has signed a flurry of executive orders that clawed back progress on women's reproductive rights, effectively banned Muslims from enering the United States, and reversed important environmental protections. His proposed "hard power" budget shreds vital programs and begins the dismantling of whole sections of government. And despite setbacks, the Republican administration continues to advanced on its promise to repeal Obamacare with replacement legislation that de-funds Planned Parenthood and leaves millions without healthcare. All the while, his fledgling administration is mired in controversy. 

It's little wonder, then, that this president has drawn citizens to the streets, to airports, to town hall meetings to raise our voices in opposition to his dangerous policies. And at every rally and protest, we bring signs. Beautiful, outrageous, poignant, and pointed signs.

The First 100 Days: Activism in a Divided America catalogs those signs and the stories behind them. Citizen Activists are invited to share their photographs to be collected in a coffee-table-style book with two purposes: to honor the forceful, peaceful engagement of Americans of every color and stripe as they make their voices heard, and to raise funds for the programs and organizations gutted by Trump's cruel agenda. Currently, we are planning two editions: The Women's Health Edition supports Planned Parenthood and other community health initiatives. The Arts and Science Edition funds arts and environmental education organizations. 

All profits raised through this campaign will directly benefit organizations that provide critical services, advocacy and education for communities that are at-risk by the Trump administration's heartless budget priorities. Organizations that will benefit from this project include:

  • Planned Parenthood
  • The Environmental Defense Fund
  • The National Guild for Community Arts Education

By contributing to this campaign, you become an activist in your own right, showing your support for the people, program,s and issues that our current government deems unimportant.

The First 100 Days of Activism Project is curated by journalist and photographer Chris Shipley. You are invited to submit your photos and stories to be considered for inclusion on the First 100 Days website and/or one of its print editions.

The postcards, art photos, and books produced by this campaign are of the highest quality at the most reasonable cost so that 100% of the profit goes to the organizations doing great work in communities across America. 

We've set a minimum target of $25,000, and we hope, through your generosity, we can do even more for these fine non-profits.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't make a financial contribution? That's okay. You can have a positive impact on your community by helping to spread the word. Please share this campaign on Facebook and tweet your support using the hashtag  #100DaysProject.

Do you have photos and stories from your demonstrations? Share your photos so that we can consider including them on the First 100 Days website and/or one of its print editions.

From the bottom of our hearts: THANK YOU!

story:
A little bit about me:

Hi! My name is Elizabeth, live in Venezuela and I am fifteen years old. I started in the world of cosplay two, three years ago and has not been easy, but I have not given up. I see a good time for each cosplay because I like my clothes remain the cutest possible (since I make by hand); the magic of cosplay is that people, to see, to feel excited. We lead a very nice impression.

I always had the dream of being cosplayer "professional", the problem is the monetary burden that this entails. Here in my country, it is very difficult to get the necessary equipment to make a quality cosplay (whether wigs, makeup, accessories... in short, a multitude of things) , therefore I buy things online, and here's the question: I have no money for such quality implements.

What I will use the money?

My idea is to use the money raised for everything related to the cosplays I want to do (and they are many), from wigs and contact lenses, to suit and accessories. All.

I plan to make five to seven cosplays (all depends on how much money can raise), three of Vocaloid: Hatsune Miku (I LOVE MIKU), Rin Kagamine and Luka Megurine. One of Yuno Gasai, a gender bender of Noiz (DRAMAtical Murders), cosplay of Victorique, of Gosick, Daenerys Targaryen, of Game of Thrones

In doing so, I will open a Facebook page where they can follow me on this colorful journey. Cosplays that there would go out doing so they could see them, also pictures of the conventions that go.

Anyway, I think that's all I had and to say. Please go to the end and read everything.

 

See you later!

story:
Dear Friends, AUNTY!, an exhibition of more than 120 rare images from The McKinley Collection, my personal archive, originally co-curated with award-winning photographer Laylah Amatullah Barrayn, closed at United Photo Industries (UPI) gallery in New York City in February 2019.  During its three month run, it garnered acclaim in the international press and unprecedented attendance.  Now we are fulfilling one of my biggest dreams for The McKinley Collection: taking the photographs to their origins! (Ghana is a place of my own origins too, in several senses. It has been the mainstay of my creative work since 1991, including a Fulbright tenure where I did the research for my book INDIGO. I lived in Accra for years. And I have Ghanaian siblings.)  

Your contributions will support:

  •  A collaborative relationship with United Photo Industries, who will guide the design and production; transport; permit obtaining; and installation of large-scale weatherized exhibition banners in the tradition of UPI's The Fence, which brings photography to non-traditional venues.     
  • Transport and insurance for an Accra launch featuring the original photographs.
  • Transport to Ghana and transport and housing of crew at installation sites in Accra, Northern Ghana, and the Volta region; local artists and art professionals who will guide public interactions, oral history collection, and inquiry-based explorations that transform the photos from art objects to public repository, "activating" The McKinley Collection.

 

ABOUT AUNTY!

AUNTY! is the first show of its kind.  Featuring the earliest colonial images of African women to the contemporary, it represents the complete arc of 150 years of photo image making on the continent, The exhibition constitutes an uncovering of the beauty of African women and their worlds within fractured and layered colonial histories, and also in the collaborative, honorific spaces of African-owned studios. 

The Ghana exhibition, is a historic return, and an opportunity for Ghanaians and the many travelers marking 2019 as the The Year of Return, to view these images in context. Some of the women featured in images at Independence celebrations, or in the kinds of 1950s-1970s nightclubs made iconic by photographers like Seydou Keita and Malick Sidibe will be present at the exhibition.  And the works of these two famed photographers will be present too, alongside ones from the earliest African and European studios, vernacular images by unknown camera artists, and the ground-breaking photography of contemporary African women--historically absent until post-Independence--and men. 

Digging into history and offering a glimpse of a future narrative, the show features some 100 archival, vintage and contemporary photographs from The McKinley Collection, a trove of photographic prints, cartes de visite and postcards spanning the African continent. As Remi Onabanjo comments for The New York Times, Aunty! "exalts [African women's] beauty on their own terms."  She recognizes, "With these early images included alongside modern and contemporary works, you’re really getting a full sweep of time and a subversive perspective on how to investigate the history of photography, through its relation tied to black African women as subjects. It also hints at the future, where more women of African descent are placed as curators, conservators and historians of the archive,” she explained. “This is a groundswell moment, showing that the medium isn’t just for the ‘modern masters’ of documentary photography, but also is embedded in a larger geographical scope of circulation and production, of subjects and individuals. We can afford to have some room.”

“Doing the work of tracing agency and power relationships, acknowledging the place of black African women inside of these networks, is one of the largest honors one can do,” Ms. Onabanjo continues. 

Thank you for joining me on this exciting journey!  Your support means everything to our success.  Please stay tuned as I update you in emails, and by Instagram and Facebook.  It's going to be an eye-opening several months!

Love,

Catherine

story:
Image by Rebecca Holbrook-Erhart, from Hidden Archive.

 

"In the process of doing their work, photographers inevitably generate archives. These two photographers think their way with and through the things of a world that is aloof yet simultaneously available to our perceptions, our curiosity, and our projections." — Ray Klimek

 

Short Summary

I’m seeking support to self-publish a book called Unpacked Box, a project featuring newly published photographic works from James Luckett and Rebecca Holbrook-Erhart, and an insightful essay by Ray Klimek. This project develops the potential meanings of photo-images and their changes over time, and gives space for the artist/viewer interpretation.

Who makes an image, and what happens to the leftover, draft, mistaken, and forgotten images for a project over time? Who views the image, who owns the right to give the image meaning, and in what way do our personal images speak to larger concerns about historical context, social and cultural movements, and our human place within larger geographic space, geologic and myth-time. These are questions I keep asking as I work through this book project.

My goal: A thoughtfully curated book which begins with a single question: 

What do artist's unused images mean now?

• • •

Read more about how this project started: 

Tangling with Forgotten Photographs on Medium.com

‘Unpacked Box’ to Examine Crucial Essence of Discarded Images — Profile on WOUB.ORG

Examining the Message of the Discarded Image — Interview on WOUB.ORG [Soundcloud]

 

Artists of the Unpacked Box

Rebecca Holbrook-Erhart

Kentucky, born and raised. Relocated to the Chicagoland area from Eastern KY and Southeastern OH in Summer 2013. Her work rests on the power of the photograph to document both the familial and familiar, and in doing so, to reveal our subjective, interior interpretations of the images we make, keep, and tell. This work is difficult, emotionally fraught stuff lying just beneath the veneer of everyday places and things.

One project I want to share here is Rebecca's expansive project The Promise, a powerful book of images and texts dealing with loss, passages of time, memories, and traveling bodies through the lens of recorded and archived personal moments. This book keeps a heavy story, making available the variety of detail often lost in the wake of family change, and personal grief. These details crystalize with time: phone calls, shared meals, hotel stays, arguments, and family gatherings become part of the complex ground upon which we all tell our stories, and make her personal narrative a universal one. 

Rebecca has an M.F.A. in Photography and Integrated Media is from Ohio University, and an M.A. in Art from Marshall University, and for the last few years has worked on staff at the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago.

 

James Luckett

Working for over twenty years in art and photography and exhibited nationally, James Luckett has an M.F.A. from the University of Arizona, worked as a master printer in a forensic photography lab and taught award winning photography classes in Tucson and Chicago. A recipient of a 2011 Ohio Arts Council Individual Excellence Award, James is also a master of soups, salads, comfort food, and a super star baker of breads in Yellow Springs, Ohio.

His self published 2009 photography book Suginami, an exploration of the ways the landscape layers in the edges of a frame and of the space of discovery between the viewfinder and the eye, was developed from daily walks through the neighborhood where he lived in Tokyo at the time.  Sheila Newberry writes about it in Walks through Suginami, and Stacy Platt in One Thing Done Two Ways.

Perhaps you too have encountered this artist's work at Wittenberg University, The University of Arizona Museum of Art, Kenyon College, Newcastle University, or the Photographic Center Northwest, among many others. 

James was born in Stuttgart and, following the pleasures of living and working in Olympia, Tokyo and Ann Arbor, has settled his studio and darkroom in Springfield, Ohio. His interests and exploits are detailed on his long- running, ever-evolving, always-accumulating website, Consumptive.org, and here— @consumptive.

 

Ray Klimek

I met Ray at Ohio University in Athens in 2012. Ray's work addresses landscape and place-making through the lens of history and fantasy. His depth and breadth of literary and art historical knowledge is overwhelming, at any point in a given conversation he will connect an artist's choice of material or method to the work of a little known poet, a crime novel character, a fleeting image in a jazz documentary, or the sounds coming through a studio window.

Ray has an M.F.A. in Photography and an M.A. in English Literature from Rutgers University, and has staged solo exhibitions of his work at Unsmoke Systems Artspace (Braddock, PA), Stevenson Gallery at Ohio University (Chillicothe, OH), the ARC Gallery (Chicago, IL), Marietta College Gallery (Marietta, OH), Roy G Biv Gallery (Columbus, OH), Zobole Gallery (South Wales, UK), Sordoni Gallery (Wilkes-Barre, PA),and the GPF Gallery (South Wales, UK). 

Ray is the 2013 Ohio University Research Council Grant recipient, was awarded a 2004 International Center of Photography-The Tierney Family Foundation Grant, and a 2003 Teaneck, NJ Grant from The Puffin Foundation. His teaching straddles studio arts, art history & theory, film, and literary courses, reaching back decades at variety of institutions.

His writings expand the conversation outward from the visual, comparisons and metaphor spiraling out toward an ever reaching horizon line. His essay How the Light Gets In: Notes on James Benning’s Ten Skies, cemented my interest in making space in this project for his writing.

• • •

 

Book Design/Layout: I am thrilled to work with a top notch graphic designer and friend, Qing Wang, to take my rough book design and make it shine. Her input and thoughtful approach to design, font choices, and layout cannot be overstated.

Please consider supporting these artists—every contribution is helpful!

Image by James Luckett.

Publishing is a tool for asking questions, a way to collaborate with others, and is becoming part of my own artistic studio practice. The book as form can challenge artists to re-examine old images, and re-consider time and context in thinking about the meanings of photographs.

 

What We Need & What You Get

What we need is two fold.

FIRST, we need your monetary support, at any level. This helps us get from designed concept to bound & finished book. Unpacked Box is about 80% completed, the design files will undergo one final round of review with the designer, before we are prepared to contract with a book printing house to begin printing proofs. This means we will be able to turn around a finished book very quickly from the time we meet out funding goals.

SECOND, we need you to share this project with as many people as possible on Facebook, and Instagram. Every share helps, and is greatly appreciated!

 

Cost Breakdown:

  • This campaign goal is $3,600 which will provide needed funds to accomplish the follow:
    • $2,900: Printing and shipping 250 copies of the 8"x8" hardbound book
    • $300: Compensation for my kind and generous graphic designer
    • $250: Additional shipping costs for delivery to campaign supporters
    • $250: Shipping, postage, marketing campaign materials for distributing books to libraries, bookstores, and potential collections
    • Total costs—$3,700
      • ​Book launch event/marketing costs to be determined by success of this campaign

Perks:

  • Featured perk: For just $75—receive a copy of the book, Unpacked Box, signed by all featured artists combined, with your name in the recognition page of the book. 
  • Donors to this campaign can get a copy of the finished book for $25— Until August 1st!  After August 1st, pre-orders will be $30.
  • Check out the perks sections for the rest!

    Contingency plans:
  • If we do not meet our funding goal, but we can raise at least 75%, we will adjust the total size of the print run down to the largest number in our capacity (est. 100 copies)
     
  • If we raise at least 50% of our goal, we will adjust the printing materials, and total number of copies to meet a small-run contract of 50 copies, and use this as leverage to propose funding and granting opportunities for a larger run in the future.

Image by Rebecca Holbrook-Erhart.

 

The Impact

Your contributions and support is essential to make this project happen. It's not simply a matter of money. Ask most every artist, they'll willingly tell you that money is important, but social support, meaningful advocacy, and standing with those who are making important work is invaluable. This artist book project is unique in that it balances focus on three individual artists making highly interesting work in their own right, in various forms, some visual and some textual.

Your backing helps each of the works in this book reach a wider audience, and acts as a vote for the endless hours each artist spends making, building, gathering, and editing bodies of work.

Your contribution also brands the leftovers from each project in archived folders, boxes, binders, and hard drives, as potentially meaningful secondary, and tertiary projects worth considering. 

 

Challenges

Books are everywhere, connecting with book buyers is tough, and most of all, publishing is expensive. I believe in the value of this project. I know that by working together with others interested in artist projects, we can create a book with lasting value, doing justice to the words and images on the page.

Distribution is a challenge— we are developing a strategy to get this book into the hands of book sellers, librarians, curators, and art and photo book collectors over the next 6 months. We can always use your help!

Image by James Luckett.

 

Other Helpful Support

I value your interest in this project. Please connect with me on Instagram, Facebook, or Twitter, and share this campaign with the people you know— every share helps!

Please find time to explore the work of the artists featured in UNPACKED BOX:

Ray Klimek: http://rayklimek.com/home.html
James Luckett: http://consumptive.org/
Rebecca Holbrook-Erhart: http://rebeccaholbrook.net/home.html

Medium: "Tangling With Forgotten Photographs"

This project develops the potential meanings of photo-images and their changes over time, and gives space for the artist/viewer interpretation.
Who makes an image, and what happens to the leftover, draft, mistaken, and forgotten images for a project over time? Who views the image, who owns the right to give the image meaning, and in what way do our personal images speak to larger concerns about historical context, social and cultural movements, and our human place within larger geographic space, geologic and myth-time. These are questions I keep asking as I work through this book project.
My goal: A thoughtfully curated book which begins with a single question: 
What do artist's unused images mean now?
• • •
Read more about how this project started: 
Tangling with Forgotten Photographs on Medium.com
‘Unpacked Box’ to Examine Crucial Essence of Discarded Images — Profile on WOUB.ORG
Examining the Message of the Discarded Image — Interview on WOUB.ORG [Soundcloud]
 
Artists of the Unpacked Box
Rebecca Holbrook-Erhart
Kentucky, born and raised. Relocated to the Chicagoland area from Eastern KY and Southeastern OH in Summer 2013. Her work rests on the power of the photograph to document both the familial and familiar, and in doing so, to reveal our subjective, interior interpretations of the images we make, keep, and tell. This work is difficult, emotionally fraught stuff lying just beneath the veneer of everyday places and things.
One project I want to share here is Rebecca's expansive project The Promise, a powerful book of images and texts dealing with loss, passages of time, memories, and traveling bodies through the lens of recorded and archived personal moments. This book keeps a heavy story, making available the variety of detail often lost in the wake of family change, and personal grief. These details crystalize with time: phone calls, shared meals, hotel stays, arguments, and family gatherings become part of the complex ground upon which we all tell our stories, and make her personal narrative a universal one. 
Rebecca has an M.F.A. in Photography and Integrated Media is from Ohio University, and an M.A. in Art from Marshall University, and for the last few years has worked on staff at the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago.
 
James Luckett
Working for over twenty years in art and photography and exhibited nationally, James Luckett has an M.F.A. from the University of Arizona, worked as a master printer in a forensic photography lab and taught award winning photography classes in Tucson and Chicago. A recipient of a 2011 Ohio Arts Council Individual Excellence Award, James is also a master of soups, salads, comfort food, and a super star baker of breads in Yellow Springs, Ohio.
His self published 2009 photography book Suginami, an exploration of the ways the landscape layers in the edges of a frame and of the space of discovery between the viewfinder and the eye, was developed from daily walks through the neighborhood where he lived in Tokyo at the time.  Sheila Newberry writes about it in Walks through Suginami, and Stacy Platt in One Thing Done Two Ways.
Perhaps you too have encountered this artist's work at Wittenberg University, The University of Arizona Museum of Art, Kenyon College, Newcastle University, or the Photographic Center Northwest, among many others. 
James was born in Stuttgart and, following the pleasures of living and working in Olympia, Tokyo and Ann Arbor, has settled his studio and darkroom in Springfield, Ohio. His interests and exploits are detailed on his long- running, ever-evolving, always-accumulating website, Consumptive.org, and here— @consumptive.
 
Ray Klimek
I met Ray at Ohio University in Athens in 2012. Ray's work addresses landscape and place-making through the lens of history and fantasy. His depth and breadth of literary and art historical knowledge is overwhelming, at any point in a given conversation he will connect an artist's choice of material or method to the work of a little known poet, a crime novel character, a fleeting image in a jazz documentary, or the sounds coming through a studio window.
Ray has an M.F.A. in Photography and an M.A. in English Literature from Rutgers University, and has staged solo exhibitions of his work at Unsmoke Systems Artspace (Braddock, PA), Stevenson Gallery at Ohio University (Chillicothe, OH), the ARC Gallery (Chicago, IL), Marietta College Gallery (Marietta, OH), Roy G Biv Gallery (Columbus, OH), Zobole Gallery (South Wales, UK), Sordoni Gallery (Wilkes-Barre, PA),and the GPF Gallery (South Wales, UK). 
Ray is the 2013 Ohio University Research Council Grant recipient, was awarded a 2004 International Center of Photography-The Tierney Family Foundation Grant, and a 2003 Teaneck, NJ Grant from The Puffin Foundation. His teaching straddles studio arts, art history & theory, film, and literary courses, reaching back decades at variety of institutions.
His writings expand the conversation outward from the visual, comparisons and metaphor spiraling out toward an ever reaching horizon line. His essay How the Light Gets In: Notes on James Benning’s Ten Skies, cemented my interest in making space in this project for his writing.
• • •
 
Book Design/Layout: I am thrilled to work with a top notch graphic designer and friend, Qing Wang, to take my rough book design and make it shine. Her input and thoughtful approach to design, font choices, and layout cannot be overstated.
Please consider supporting these artists—every contribution is helpful!


Image by James Luckett.
Publishing is a tool for asking questions, a way to collaborate with others, and is becoming part of my own artistic studio practice. The book as form can challenge artists to re-examine old images, and re-consider time and context in thinking about the meanings of photographs.
 
What We Need & What You Get
What we need is two fold.
FIRST, we need your monetary support, at any level. This helps us get from designed concept to bound & finished book. Unpacked Box is about 80% completed, the design files will undergo one final round of review with the designer, before we are prepared to contract with a book printing house to begin printing proofs. This means we will be able to turn around a finished book very quickly from the time we meet out funding goals.
SECOND, we need you to share this project with as many people as possible on Facebook, and Instagram. Every share helps, and is greatly appreciated!
 
Cost Breakdown:
This campaign goal is $3,600 which will provide needed funds to accomplish the follow:
$2,900: Printing and shipping 250 copies of the 8"x8" hardbound book
$300: Compensation for my kind and generous graphic designer
$250: Additional shipping costs for delivery to campaign supporters
$250: Shipping, postage, marketing campaign materials for distributing books to libraries, bookstores, and potential collections

Total costs—$3,700
​Book launch event/marketing costs to be determined by success of this campaign



Perks:


Featured perk: For just $75—receive a copy of the book, Unpacked Box, signed by all featured artists combined, with your name in the recognition page of the book. 
Donors to this campaign can get a copy of the finished book for $25— Until August 1st!  After August 1st, pre-orders will be $30.
Check out the perks sections for the rest!Contingency plans:

If we do not meet our funding goal, but we can raise at least 75%, we will adjust the total size of the print run down to the largest number in our capacity (est. 100 copies) 
If we raise at least 50% of our goal, we will adjust the printing materials, and total number of copies to meet a small-run contract of 50 copies, and use this as leverage to propose funding and granting opportunities for a larger run in the future.



Image by Rebecca Holbrook-Erhart.
 
The Impact
Your contributions and support is essential to make this project happen. It's not simply a matter of money. Ask most every artist, they'll willingly tell you that money is important, but social support, meaningful advocacy, and standing with those who are making important work is invaluable. This artist book project is unique in that it balances focus on three individual artists making highly interesting work in their own right, in various forms, some visual and some textual.
Your backing helps each of the works in this book reach a wider audience, and acts as a vote for the endless hours each artist spends making, building, gathering, and editing bodies of work.
Your contribution also brands the leftovers from each project in archived folders, boxes, binders, and hard drives, as potentially meaningful secondary, and tertiary projects worth considering. 

 

Challenges
Books are everywhere, connecting with book buyers is tough, and most of all, publishing is expensive. I believe in the value of this project. I know that by working together with others interested in artist projects, we can create a book with lasting value, doing justice to the words and images on the page.


Distribution is a challenge— we are developing a strategy to get this book into the hands of book sellers, librarians, curators, and art and photo book collectors over the next 6 months. We can always use your help!

Image by James Luckett.
 

Other Helpful Support
I value your interest in this project. Please connect with me on Instagram, Facebook, or Twitter, and share this campaign with the people you know— every share helps!

Please find time to explore the work of the artists featured in UNPACKED BOX:
Ray Klimek: http://rayklimek.com/home.htmlJames Luckett: http://consumptive.org/Rebecca Holbrook-Erhart: http://rebeccaholbrook.net/home.html
Medium: "Tangling With Forgotten Photographs"

story:
#FeedOn is a new social awareness campaign by RÅN studio and the Association of Breastfeeding Mothers (ABM), using photography and film to help normalise breastfeeding in public.

After the huge success of our previous public awareness campaign, ABM asked us to take the creative lead in developing and producing a new campaign that is even bigger and this time - nationwide. In June this year ABM is celebrating their 40th birthday and with this project we are hoping to raise awareness of the incredible work breastfeeding volunteers and supporters are doing in the UK where breastfeeding rates are amongst the lowest in the world.

Our earlier project featured a series of women freely breastfeeding in public places across landmark locations in London. One year on we are about to photograph 40 women in 6 different cities across the UK (if we reach our goal we can make this 7 and include Northern Ireland).

With this project we are hoping to help normalise breastfeeding as well as create yet again absolutely stunning imagery shot on 35mm film accompanied by a short documentary.

To see our previous campaign featured on billboards across London follow the link. 

Hear from the mothers who took part in our previous  campaign

 

 

WHO WE ARE

As a studio we always strive to create work that engages with people and encourages conversations. RÅN studio was founded by Agatha A. Nitecka and Robert Appleton. We have spent a combined 12 years working within the film industry and have delivered creative content for productions that range from independent films to larger scale studio films. 

The Association of Breastfeeding Mothers (ABM) is a voluntary organisation founded in 1979 by mothers already experienced in breastfeeding counselling. As well as supporting mums and families and offering training, they represent breastfeeding families at a national advocacy level.

You’ll be able to read more about the people behind this project below.

 

 

WHY MAKE #FeedOn?

This campaign matters a lot to us. We want to show beautiful interactions between mothers, parents, children and the cities across the UK, and to reframe how people engage with breastfeeding in public. #FeedOn is a social awareness campaign and we hope that with our images and a short film we can create change and involve men and women, healthcare professionals and mothers, politicians and councils in a conversation. 

Breastfeeding rates are substantially lower among very young mothers and disadvantaged socio-economic groups. This impacts the existing health inequalities and contributes further to the cycle of deprivation. The UNICEF Baby Friendly Initiative commissioned a report which estimated that ‘moderate increases in breastfeeding would save up to £40 million in NHS expenditure based on fewer General Practitioner consultations and hospital admissions’ (source: RCPCH). 

With our project we’d like to support the call on the UK Government to reinstate the UK-wide Infant Feeding Survey, which was cancelled in 2015.

 

 

WHY NOW?

2019 marks the 40th anniversary of the founding of ABM. This makes it a perfect time to highlight their work as well as create imagery that will encourage conversations and normalise breastfeeding in the UK. We believe the UK is a better place because of our mix of ethnicities, religions and cultures which is why it has always been our aim to represent the diversity of the UK.

This project is important to us because we feel that now more than ever there is a need for connection and understanding of others. We want to engage with communities all over the UK and we’ll be shooting in Bristol, Barrow, Cardiff, Cambridge, Glasgow and Manchester. If we reach our goal, we will be able to include Northern Ireland in this campaign. 

 

 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

 

By crowdfunding this project, we would like to ensure that this campaign has as far a reach as possible. The world of breastfeeding support is under a lot of pressure and there have been many cuts to breastfeeding support services. In a UNICEF Baby Friendly survey, more than half of areas in England were reporting cuts to breastfeeding groups and cuts to children centre services. Nearly 60% reported cuts of front-line health visiting services (source: UNICEF).

We want to expand the positive reaction that came from our previous public awareness campaign and enable a more expanded project not only through the photography and a short film but also to mobilise something much bigger.

Our goal for this campaign is £10,000 and this is to cover Agatha’s and Robert’s travel, meal and accommodation costs while shooting in Bristol, Barrow, Cardiff, Cambridge, Glasgow and Manchester. 

The photographs will be taken using analogue cameras and shot on 35mm film and a short documentary will be developed alongside. Our costs will also include production and photo development.

If we reach our goal, we can include Northern Ireland in this project which is hugely important to us as it will allow us to represent the entire UK! 

We appreciate all support and every pledge will help us bring this project to life. Even if we don’t reach our goal every contribution goes a long way.

We’ve got many exciting perks for you to pick from (listed on the right) and some of them are project-specific. We’ll be creating those over the coming months and you can be the first ones to receive them. We’ll have #FeedOn pin badges, tote bags, posters and a campaign catalogue. Be the change you want to see and show your support!

If we exceed our goal, any additional funds will go directly to the ABM to help them in their work of training mothers to support other mothers with breastfeeding, so that more families can breastfeed their babies for as long as they want to.

 

 

THE IMPACT

This campaign is not about expecting every mother to breastfeed, but we want everyone to have a choice. This isn’t about wanting 100% of families to breastfeed, it’s about making sure that all the people who want to breastfeed feel like they can. We want families to have a choice, rather than being let down by a lack of support – both breastfeeding support and support from society.

In the UK, we don’t all feel entirely comfortable with breastfeeding out and about. Every single time we see a mother breastfeeding, whether in real life or just an image, it helps to normalise what should be entirely normal. It helps the next woman we see in the cafe or on the train. It helps the little girl who may not breastfeed for another 20 years. It makes a difference. It’s no exaggeration to say this project will have an impact that could change lives.

 

Our previous campaign was featured on billboards across London

 

 

PEOPLE BEHIND THIS PROJECT

Agatha A. Nitecka, co-founder of RÅN studio

Agatha has collaborated with award-winning directors, actors and production companies and has shot exclusively on 35mm film for Universal Studios, BBC Films, Working Title, Film4, The Bureau and many others. 

She has photographed among others many award winning actors including Eddie Redmayne, Saoirse Ronan, Ben Whishaw, Rachel Weisz, Rachel McAdams, Ian McKellen, Laura Linney, Robert Pattinson, Alicia Vikander, Amber Heard, Charlotte Rampling, Tom Courtney. 

And has worked with award winning directors including Andrea Arnold, Joanna Hogg, Clio Barnard, Tom Hooper, Andrew Haigh, Francis Lee and Sebastián Lelio.

She is also an ambassador for the AllBright Academy, which helps women gain the skills, confidence and network needed to achieve their career goals.

Some of Agatha’s film set work is available for sale when you support the project. Agatha’s work is not often available for sale so do make sure you grab this opportunity!

You can find her full film credits on the IMDb page here. 

 

Robert Appleton, co-founder of RÅN studio

Robert graduated with a degree in Filmmaking from Manchester School of Art. Last year he  additionally studied film editing at the internationally renowned National Film and Television School based in London. 

He has successfully worked with London Design Festival, City York Council, South East Makers Club and University of the Arts London, as well as shot additional EPK content for film productions. 

Throughout his creative career Robert has worked on several social projects maintaining a desire to create content for social change and good.

For the past few years he has been working closely with councils helping the departments for special educational needs. The content he creates clearly communicates policy and council initiatives while making sure that the voices of council workers, teachers, carers, parents and the young people involved are all present and heard. 

Working solely within digital mediums he understands and taps into creative solutions that make the digital format more tactile.

 

Emma Pickett, Chair of the Association of Breastfeeding Mothers

Emma is an ABM breastfeeding counsellor and lactation consultant (IBCLC). Emma is also the author of  ‘The Breast Book’: a puberty book with a difference – it’s the when, why and how of breasts.

 

 

RISKS & CHALLENGES

A selection of Agatha's film work shot on 35mm film, from left to right: Saoirse Ronan (How I Live Now), Rachel Weisz with Rachel McAdams (Disobedience), Kaya Scodelario (Wuthering Heights), Eddie Redmayne (The Danish Girl), Alicia Vikander (The Danish Girl), Charlotte Rampling with Tom Courtney (45 Years)

 

Every creative and social project has risks involving production. Good news is we are an experienced team with a proven track record. The films we worked on include Disobedience, God’s Own Country, Notes on Blindness, The Danish Girl, Mr. Holmes and Wuthering Heights.

Our previous projects were featured amongst others in The New York Times, The New Yorker, Der Spiegel, Le Monde, Financial Times, The Guardian, The Observer, The Telegraph, The Times, The Independent, Tatler, Vogue UK, Interview, AnOther, Vice and Esquire.

We commit to keeping you informed along the way and doing everything we can to make sure we get the #FeedOn campaign and all the perks to you as soon as possible.

We're determined to create stunning imagery and help normalise breastfeeding in the UK and we appreciate your support in helping us deliver a high-quality campaign that will be enjoyed by the public as well as invite a further dialogue about breastfeeding in the country and possibly worldwide.

 

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We’d be incredibly grateful if you could help us spread the word about our crowdfunding campaign for #FeedOn. Indiegogo has available tools to share the campaign quickly, you can find the icons for Facebook and Twitter next to the video above. You can also instantly generate a link which would make it easy for you to share with anyone, or feel free to embed the video too. 

We’d absolutely love it if you forwarded this link to your network using social media or a personal message!

Share our campaign page: www.igg.me/at/feedon

 

 

FINAL NOTES

#FeedOn is a collaboration between RÅN studio and ABM only. No other companies are involved.

We welcome press enquiries, our press package is available on request, please email: hello@ranstudio.co.uk

Your contributions on Indiegogo will go towards making #FeedOn and bringing it into the world. Please follow us on social media for updates on our progress - links to subscribe and share are below. Stay tuned for more updates!

Website: www.ranstudio.co.uk

Instagram: @RANstudioLDN

Twitter: @RANstudioLDN

 

Our past clients:
